pages.title: Mesihi of Prishtina
pages.text:
'''Mesihi (Messiah) of Prishtina''', known in [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]] as '''Priştinali Mesihi''' was one of the best known [[Ottoman poetry|Ottoman poets]] of late 15th - early 16th century during the [[Bayezid II]]'s era  and is regarded as one of the earliest [[Albanians|Albanian]] poets in overall.<ref name="Norris">{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RGmzir-ITtUC&pg=PA62&dq=mesihi+norris&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1I5gVeLKH4efgwS6ooG4DQ&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=mesihi%20norris&f=false| page=62|year=1993| publisher= 	Columbia, S.C : University of South Carolina Pres| isbn= 9780872499775| title=Islam in the Balkans: Religion and Society Between Europe and the Arab World|author=H. T. Norris|}}</ref><ref name="Marcel-John">{{citation| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5pAwqsSyTlsC&pg=PA286&dq=mesihi+of+prishtina&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_IxgVdz5HZODgwSfg4GIDw&ved=0CDEQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=mesihi%20of%20prishtina&f=false|page=286|title=The Literary Cultures of East-Central Europe series: History of the Literary Cultures of East-Central Europe: Junctures and Disjunctures in the 19th and 20th centuries| author=	Marcel Cornis-Pope, John Neubauer| publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company| year=2006| oclc= 	234173843| isbn= 978-9027234537| volume=II| series= 	Comparative history of literatures in European languages (book 20)}}</ref>

==Life and work==
He was born in [[Prishtina]],<ref name="BEI"/>  then [[Ottoman Empire]], possibly around 1470. He was an Albanian<ref name="Marcel-John"/><ref name="Norris"/> born Isa.<ref name="Wink">{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wtcUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA1026&dq=mesihi+of+prishtina&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_IxgVdz5HZODgwSfg4GIDw&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=mesihi%20of%20prishtina&f=false|title=Al-hind: The Making of the Indo-islamic World| author=André Wink| page=1026|publisher=E.J. Brill| year=1990|isbn=9789004092495|oclc= 	21761923}}</ref> He moved to [[Istambul]] at an early age and lived there until his death around 1512.<ref name="Norris"/><ref name="Elsie">{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pg-aeA-nUeAC&pg=PA187&dq=mesihi+of+prishtina&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_IxgVdz5HZODgwSfg4GIDw&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=mesihi%20of%20prishtina&f=false| author=[[Robert Elsie]]| page=187|title=Historical Dictionary of Kosovo|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=2001| series= 	Historical dictionaries of Europe| volume=79|edition=2|isbn= 	9780810874831}}</ref>

Mesihi became a ''softa'', a [[theology|theological]] or ''[[madrasa]]'' student,<ref name="BEI"/> and soon distinguished himself as a [[calligrapher]]. He was able to gain the support of the [[Grand Vizier]] [[Hadım Ali Pasha|Khadim Ali Pasha]], and became his ''[[diwan (poetry)|diwan]]'' secretary, who had had plenty of reasons to be annoyed with Mesihi. Mesihi is mentioned as non-disciplined, running after a pleasure-oriented life, and conscienceless towards the performance of his official duties. The vizier, of Albanian descend himself,<ref>{{cite book|title=Türkçülük ve Türkçülük mücadeleleri tarihi|year=1969|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dJSgAAAAMAAJ&q=Hadım+Ali+Paşa|page=53|trans-title=Turkism and Turkism struggle history| author= Ali Kemal Meram |location= Istanbul |publisher= Kültür Kitabevi|oclc= 	29396792|quote=10 – Hadım Ali Paşa (Arnavut-devşirme, köle)}}</ref> is quoted to have called him "street-Arab"<ref name="Wink"/> or "street boy"<ref name="Elsie"/> (Ottoman: Sheher Oglani). Nevertheless, Mesihi held his position until Khadim Pasha term ended in 1511 after his death during the [[Şahkulu Rebellion]]. Mesihi composed a deeply felt elegy on Vizier's death. He tried getting protection some other high rank officials. According to [[Ashik Çelebi]], he did not succeed in getting protection from [[Yunus Pasha]], or [[Nishandji Tadji-zade Dja'fer Çelebi]], and also failed in his attempts to get patronage from [[Selim I]].<ref name="Wink"/> According to the French scholar [[Victor L. Ménage]], he was in service of Yunnus Pasha, which seems to be more reliable.<ref name="Wink"/>

Mesihi's place in the Ottoman ''diwan'' poetry is that of a highly gifted and original poet. His language is relatively plain and clear, his manner devoid of affectation. A touch of [[Rumelia|Rumelian dialect]] here and there is of particular interest. Mesihi's not-especially voluminous ''diwan'' has not been printed. Several critical studies on his work do exist.<ref name="Wink"/> His ''Murabba' -i bahâr'' (Ode to Spring) was translated and published by the [[Oriental studies|Orientalist]] [[Sir William Jones]], and remained for a long time best known Turkish poem in Europe.<ref name="Marcel-John"/> His ''Shehr-engiz'' became popular and he had many followers in this poetic genre. He is regarded as "the third great Ottoman poet and the greatest lyric poet before [[Bâkî]]".<ref name="BEI">{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L1oUAQAAIAAJ&q=mesihi+of+prishtina&dq=mesihi+of+prishtina&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EKJgVfy4PIihgwT104D4DQ&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBjgK| page=739|volume=3| title=Biographical Encyclopaedia of Islam| quote=Born in Prishtina (northern Albania), he came as a youth to Constantinople where he became a softa (theological student)... Mesihi was regarded as the third great Ottoman poet and the greatest lyric poet before Baki.|publisher=Cosmo Publications| year=2006|oclc=67694633|isbn=9788130703879|author= M Th Houtsma}}</ref>

'''Mustafa Râkim''' ({{lang-ota| '''مصطفى رآقم'''}}; [[Turkish language|Modern Turkish]]: ''Mustafa Râkım'') (1757–1826), was an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[calligraphy|calligrapher]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lesartsturcs.org/calligraphy/ottoman.html|title=The Ottoman Period|publisher=Les Arts Turcs|accessdate=17 December 2011}}</ref> He extended and reformed [[Hâfiz Osman]]'s style, placing greater emphasis on technical perfection, which broadened the calligraphic art to encompass the [[Thuluth|Sülüs]] script as well as the [[Naskh (script)|Nesih]] script.<ref name=kalemguzeli>[http://www.kalemguzeli.org/index.php?go=icerikgoster2&MKNO=46&KNO=34 Mustafa Rakım Efendi]</ref>

==Life and career==
Mustafa Râkim was born in Unye on the Black Sea in 1758. When he was very young, his father, Mehmed Kaptan, took him to Istanbul to live with his brother, [[İsmail Zühdi Efendi]], who was an established calligrapher.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 98</ref> After Ismail was appointed as an instructor of calligraphy at the Imperial Palace , the young Râkim received his formal training there studying under his brother. Mustafa Râkim would become Ismail Zühidi's most celebtrated pupil.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 96</ref> 

Ismail Zühidi and Mustafa Râkim went on to develop their own style of calligraphy based on the work of [[Hâfiz Osman]]. They were able to develop a style of ''celî sülüs'' that was aesthetically pleasing, something that other calligraphers had not been able to do.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 19</ref>  Râkim also reformed the calligraphic shape of the tughra script.<ref>Ga'bor, A and Masters, B.A., ''Encyclopedia of the Ottoman Empire'', Infobase Publishing, 2010, p. 117; Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 19</ref> 

With the revolutionary changes brought about in calligraphy by Mustafa Râkim,<ref name=aksiyon>[http://www.aksiyon.biz/detay.php?id=2902 Haşim Söylemez, Türk Picassosu Rakım Efendi, Aksiyon Dergisi, Sayı 455, 25.08.2003]</ref> scholars treat Turkish calligraphic art history  into two key eras: "Pre-Râkim" and "Post-Râkim". He was able to accomplish what nobody before him could in the [[Jali (script)|Jali]]-[[Thuluth]] script and [[tughra]]s of sultans. By finding the ideal measurement between the letter thickness and pen (writing tool) thickness, he established the style and form for the ideal beauty of tughras.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 19</ref>  

He is regarded as the first great [[Turkish people|Turkish]] painter in the Western sense of painting. His bird, parrot, painting is considered to be the first [[Realism (arts)|realist]] work of Turkish painting.<ref name=ordu>[http://www.ordukulturturizm.gov.tr/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=76 Ordu İl Kültür ve Turizm Müdürlüğü web sitesi, Erişim tarihi:03.06.2011]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He drew a portrait of Sultan [[Selim III]] who was amazed by his work and recited a poem in his honor in return.

'''Hâfiz Osman''' ({{lang-ota|حافظ عثمان}} [[Turkish language|Modern Turkish]]: ''Hâfız Osman'') (1642–1698) was an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[calligrapher]] noted for improving the script and for developing a layout template for the [[hilya|hilye]] which became the classical approach to page design.

==History==
Born Osman Den Ali, in [[Istanbul]], he was of [[Dervish]] origin and worked under the name of  Hâfiz Osman.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://calligrapher.blogsome.com/2006/04/20/osman-effendi-hafiz-osman-1642-1698/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520044707/http://calligrapher.blogsome.com/2006/04/20/osman-effendi-hafiz-osman-1642-1698/ |archivedate=2009-05-20 |df= }}</ref> His father was a muezzin at the Khassèki mosque, a position which afforded he and his family great protection.<ref> Huart, C., ''Les Calligraphes et les Miniaturistes de l'Orient Musulman''  1972, p. 148 [https://archive.org/details/lescalligraphes00huargoog Digital copy (in French)]</ref>

He became an accomplished calligrapher and was a tutor to the sultans [[Ahmed II]], [[Mustafa II]] and [[Ahmed III]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://calligrapher.wordpress.com/2007/05/07/hafiz-osman-b-istanbul-1642-d-istanbul-1698/|title=Hafiz Osman (b Istanbul, 1642; d Istanbul, 1698)|first1=Yusuf ibn Aiyyoub July|last1=17|first2=2009 at 9:36|last2=Pm|date=7 May 2007|publisher=}}</ref> and was held in high esteem by the sultan [[Mustafa II]], who, according to legend often watched him work and held his inkwell as he wrote.<ref>Huart, C., ''Les Calligraphes et les Miniaturistes de l'Orient Musulman''  1972, p. 148 [https://archive.org/details/lescalligraphes00huargoog Digital copy]</ref>

He received his formal training with [[Suyolcuzade Mustafa Eyyubi]] and Derviş Ali.<ref>Suarez, M.F. and Woudhuysen, H.R. (eds), ''The Oxford companion to the Book,'' Volume 1, Oxford University Press, p. 776; M. Uğur Derman, ''Masterpieces of Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Museum'', İstanbul, Sabancı Üniversitesi. pp. 82–83, {{ISBN|978-975-8362-45-5}}</ref> He studied ''nashk'' and ''sulus'' with Derviş Ali, and was certified by Suyolcuzade Mustafa Eyyubi.<ref>Kemal Çiçek, Ercüment Kuran, Nejat Göyünç, İlber Ortaylı, ''The Great Ottoman-Turkish Civilisation,'' Volume 3, Yeni Türkiye, 2000, n.p.</ref> Osman also admired the work of the 15th-century calligrapher, [[Seyh Hamdullah]], and spent many hours copying his works assiduously in order to perfect his craft.<ref>Osborn, J.R., ''Letters of Light: Arabic Script in Calligraphy, Print, and Digital Design'', Harvard University Press, 2017, [E-book edition], n.p.</ref>

Osman revived some of the six scripts that had fallen into disuse. These scripts underwent a process of purification and became known as "Hâfiz Osman's style". The younger generation of calligraphers preferred this style, and it gradually replaced Hamdullah's style.<ref>M. Ugur Derman, "The Art of Calligraphy in the Ottoman Regime, in: Ekmeleddin Ihsanoglu (ed.), ''History of Ottoman State and Civilisation'', II, Istanbul 2003, pp 645-652</ref>

Osman was not only a fine calligrapher, but was also a master of layout. He raised text design to new heights, often incorporating different styles of calligraphy on the same page. His masterpiece is the Ottoman, ''[[Hilya|hilye]]''; a design template that includes eight distinct elements arranged aesthetically to provide for contemplative reflection and devotion. The elements are: ''Ba makan'' (prelude); ''Gobek'' (belly); ''Hilal'' (crescent); ''Ko'eler'' (corners); ''Ayak'' (verse); ''Etek'' (foot); ''Koltukar'' (alleys) and ''Pervaz'' (frame). His ''[[Hilya|hilye]]'' became the standard layout in the Ottoman world.<ref>Osborn, J.R., ''Letters of Light: Arabic Script in Calligraphy, Print, and Digital Design'', Harvard University Press, 2017, [E-book edition], n.p.</ref>  

A ''hilye'' is a calligraphic panel containing a [[hadith]]-based text describing the [[Muhammad|Prophet]]'s physical appearance and attributes. Hâfiz Osman incorporated such texts, which had been popular for some time, in a formal design that soon became standard for this art form. ''Hilye'' came to be used as wall decorations or surface adornments, fulfilling much the same function as figurative paintings in other religious traditions. While containing a concrete and artistically appealing description of Prophet's appearance, they complied with the strictures against figurative depictions of the Prophet, leaving his appearance to the viewer's imagination.<ref name="Peters2010">{{cite book|author=F. E. Peters|title=Jesus and Muhammad: Parallel Tracks, Parallel Lives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=olEi-1LZYYQC&pg=PA160|accessdate=5 November 2011|date=10 November 2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-974746-7|pages=160–161}}</ref>

Hâfiz Osman also reinvigorated Hamdullah's tradition, in particular the re-introduction of a number of scripts that had fallen into disuse. Among his surviving works are copies of the [[Koran]] held at the [[Topkapi Palace]] Museum Library in Istanbul and the Nasser D. Khalili Collection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://calligraphyqalam.com/people/hafiz-osman.html|title=CalligraphyQalam.com - Arabic, Ottoman & Persian Calligraphy - Hafiz Osman|website=calligraphyqalam.com}}</ref> The volumes of the Koran produced by Osman were among the most highly sought-after in his time.<ref>Lyons, Martyn. Books: A Living History. Los Angeles: J. Paul Getty Museum, 2011. p.48</ref>

He gave lessons to the poor on Sundays and lessons to the wealthy on Wednesdays.<ref> Huart, C., ''Les Calligraphes et les Miniaturistes de l'Orient Musulman''  1972, p. 148 [https://archive.org/details/lescalligraphes00huargoog Digital copy]</ref> Throughout his lifetime, he trained a large number of calligraphers, of whom the finest was [[Yedikuleli Seyyid 'Abdullah Efendi]]. <ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 86</ref>

==Works==
Surviving examples of his work can be found in the [[Topkapı Palace|Topkapi Collection]].<ref>''The Diez Albums: Contexts and Contents'', BRILL, c. 2016, p.136</ref>

pages.title: Küplüceli Öznur
Mustafa Halim Özyazıcı
pages.text:
{{short description|Ottoman calligrapher}}

[[File:Mustafa Halim Özyazıcı.jpg|thumb|Mustafa Halim Özyazıci (1898-1964), aged about 20 years]]
'''Mustafa Halim Özyazıcı''' (14 January, 1898 - 30 September, 1964) was an Ottoman calligrapher and one of the last of the classical Ottoman calligraphers, using the Arabic script. He was a versatile [[Calligraphy|calligrapher]] with a high level of expertise in many styles of script, but was widely regarded as a master ''celi-sulus.'' He is most noted for his work on various restoration projects, of both manuscripts and public buildings.

==Life and career==
Mustafa Halim Ozyazici was born Mustafa Abdülhalim on 14 January, 1898 in the Hazeki district of [[Istanbul]]. He was the son of Nalıncı Hacı Cemâl Efendi, originally from Crimea and his mother was Sudanese.<ref>''Islamic Arts Portal'',[https://www.ketebe.org/sanatkar/halim-ozyazici-341 Online:]</ref>

He was educated at Gülsen Junior High School, where he was given lessons in calligraphy by [[Hamid Aytaç]], who recognised his talent and encouraged him to pursue calligraphy as a career.<ref>''Islamic Arts Portal'', [https://www.ketebe.org/sanatkar/halim-ozyazici-341 Online:]; Bloom J. and Blair, S., ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Oxford University Press, 2009 Vol. 3, p. 89</ref> He later studied drawing and sculpture at the [[Academy of Fine Arts, Istanbul|Academy of Fine Arts]] in Istanbul. His formal calligraphy studies were with Hasan Riza Effendi (1849-1920) and Kamil Akdik (1862-1941) where he mastered the ''[[Thuluth|sülüs]], [[Naskh (script)|nesih]] and [[Ruqʿah script|rikā]]'' scripts. <ref>Bloom J. and Blair, S., ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Oxford University Press, 2009 Vol. 3, p. 89</ref>

In 1916, he was drafted into the [[Ottoman Army (1861–1922)|Army]]. After completing basic training he worked in the Military Printing Department and also worked in Evkāf-ı İslâmiyye Printing Press. Following his discharge from the Army in 1924, he opened an office in Bâbıâli Street where he prepared all types of calligraphy; business cards, seals and book covers. <ref>Mehmet Zeki Kuşoğlu, ''Osmanlı kartvizitleri : Hâmid Aytaç, M. Halim Özyazıcı ve Arif Hikmet Bey'in kartvizit ve hat örneklerinden bir derleme'', [Ottoman Business Cards: A compilation of business cards and calligraphy samples by Hâmid Aytaç, M. Halim Özyazıcı and Arif Hikmet Bey by Mehmet Zeki Kuşoğl'', İstanbul, Zafer Yayınları, 1996 (in Turkish)</ref> He also taught in various schools around the [[Cağaloğlu]] district of Istanbul. 

From 1927, he was employed in the Imperial Chancery.<ref>''Islamic Encyclopedia'', [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/ozyazici-mustafa-halim Online:]; ''Islamic Art Portal'', [https://www.ketebe.org/sanatkar/halim-ozyazici-341 Online:]</ref> When the Latin alphabet replaced Arabic lettering in 1928, he applied to go to Egypt, where classical calligraphy, using Arabic script, was still valued, but his application was rejected in 1929. He subsequently abandoned calligraphy altogether.<ref>Bloom J. and Blair, S., ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Oxford University Press, 2009 Vol. 3, p. 89</ref> 

However, during the 1940s, his skills in classical calligraphy found an outlet when he became part of a major restoration project which worked on repairs to numerous manuscripts in a variety of styles and the restoration of calligraphic reliefs and monumental art in historic, public buildings, including many mosques.<ref>''Islamic Arts Portal'', [https://www.ketebe.org/sanatkar/halim-ozyazici-341 Online:]; ''Islamic Encyclopedia'', [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/ozyazici-mustafa-halim Online:]</ref> In 1948, he was appointed to the position of ‘old writing teacher’ at the Academy of Fine Arts in Istanbul; a position he retained until his retirement in 1963. One of his responsibilities was to write the diplomas for those who were about to graduate from the Academy. <ref>''Islamic Encyclopedia'', [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/ozyazici-mustafa-halim (Translated from Turkish, Online:]; ''Islamic Arts Portal'',[https://www.ketebe.org/sanatkar/halim-ozyazici-341 Online:]</ref> 

He died on 30 September, 1964, ten days after being involved in a traffic accident. He was buried in the Kozlu Cemetery.<ref>''Islamic Encyclopedia'', [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/ozyazici-mustafa-halim Online:]</ref>

==Work==

Although he developed expertise in many different types of script, he was regarded as a master of ''celi-sulus'' script.<ref>Bloom J. and Blair, S., ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Oxford University Press, 2009 Vol. 3, p. 89; M. Uğur Derman, ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection'', Istanbul, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 187</ref> He wrote a number of exercise books for students to practice scripts in [[Naskh (script)|nesih]], [[Thuluth|sulus-nesih]], [[Ruqʿah script|rik'a]], [[Diwani|dı̂vânı̂]] and celı̂ dı̂vâni, and which were part of a program designed to promote the art of calligraphy. These books are still being printed and distributed to students of calligraphy.<ref>Research Centre for Islamic History, Art, and Culture, ''Newsletter'', Issues 61-71, The Centre, 2003, p. 15</ref>

==Legacy==
He is the subject of a book by M. Uğur Derman entitled, ''Hattat Mustafa Halim Özyazıcı (1898-1964)'' published in 1964. <ref>M. Uğur Derman,  ''Hattat Mustafa Halim Özyazıcı (1898-1964)'', Istanbul, Kemal Matbaası, 1964 (in Turkish)</ref>

'''Sami Efendi''' ({{lang-ota| '''سامى افندي'''}}, [[Turkish language|Modern Turkish]]: ''Hattat Mehmet Sâmi Efendi'') (1858-1912), was an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[calligrapher]]. 

==Life and work==
He was born Mehmed Sami on 13 March, 1838 in Haydarhâne district of Fatih in Istanbul.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., "Sami Eendi, İsmâil Hakkı", '' [Biographical Notes], ''Islam Encyclopedia,'' [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/sami-efendi-ismail-hakki Online (in Turkish):]; Bloom, G. and Blair, S.S., "Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture'', Vol. 3, Oxford University Press, 2009, p. 180</ref> His father was Mehmed Efendi, an official of the Quilt-makers Guild and his mother was Nefise Hanim.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 142; Bloom, G. and Blair, S.S., ''Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture, Vol. 1, Oxford University Press, 2009, p.180</ref> 

He studied calligraphy with Kibriszade Ismail Hakki Efendi and Haydar Bey (182-1870).<ref>Bloom G. and Blair, S., ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Oxford University Press, 2009 Vol. 3, p. 180</ref> He was also student of Sheikh Sadik Efendi, who had learned his art in 19th-century Bukhara and his students, including Sami, helped to carry it into the 20th-century.<ref>Ocak, M., ''The Turks: Ottomans'' Vol. e 4, Yeni Türkiye, 2002, {{ISBN|9756782552}}</ref> He was inspired by the work of [[Mustafa Râkim|Mustafa Raq'im]] (1757 - 1826)<ref>Bloom, G and Blair, S.S., "Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture'', Vol. 3, Oxford University Press, 2009, p. 180</ref> 

He also learned the art of paper making and the art of marbling paper by studying with Edhem Efendi.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., "Sami Eendi, İsmâil Hakkı", '' [Biographical Notes], ''Islam Encyclopedia,'' [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/sami-efendi-ismail-hakki Online (in Turkish):]</ref> 

His personal style was most evident with ''Celî''. These plates were generally written on black paper with yellow colored ink, or sometimes with gold.  Sami designed the most attractive designs for vowell signs, refined many aids to reading and also developed the ''tezînyat'' (decorations) and numbers. These techniques are still in use in modern calligraphy.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'', Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 19</ref> The [[Tughra]] (monogram) found its "definitive shape"  with Sami Efendi during the era of [[Abdulhamid II]].<ref>Ga'bor, A and Masters, B.A. ''Encyclopedia of the Ottoman Empire'', Infobase Publishing, 2010, p. 117</ref> 

For many years, he taught at the [[Topkapi Palace]]. His students included many calligraphers who went on to have notable careers including: Nazif Bey, Huhiso Efendi, Puza Efendi,<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'',  Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 144-45</ref> Okyay Necmeddin and Kâmil Akdik.<ref>Bloom, G and Blair, S.S., "Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture'', Vol. 3, Oxford University Press, 2009, p. 180</ref>

Following the proclamation of the Constitutional monarchy, he retired. He was paralyzed in his final years and died 1 July 1912. He was buried in the Hazrat Mosque Mosque. His former student, Hacı Kâmil Efendi (Akdik) wrote his epigraph with celî sülüs.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., "Sami Eendi, İsmâil Hakkı", '' [Biographical Notes], ''Islam Encyclopedia,'' [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/sami-efendi-ismail-hakki Online (in Turkish):]; Note that Bloom and Blair state that he was buried in the Cemetery of the Fatih Mosque, ''Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture, OUP, 2009, vol. 3, p. 180</ref>

His work adorns fountains, mosques and gravestones in Istanbul.

'''Sheikh Hamdullah''' (1436–1520) ({{lang-tr|Şeyh Hamdullah}}), born in [[Amasya]], [[Ottoman Empire]], was a master of [[Islamic calligraphy]].

==Life and work==
Sheikh Hamdullah was born in Amasya, a north-central town in Anatolia. His father, Mustafa Dede, was the Sheik of the Suhreverdi, a group that had migrated to Amasya from Central Asia.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 46</ref>

In Amasya, he studied the six scripts under the tutelage of Hayreddin Mar'asi.<ref>''Traditional Turkish Arts: Calligraphy'' Turkish Republic, Istanbul, Ministry of Culture and Tourism, n.d., p. 9</ref>  He learned the traditional method of the old masters, but struggled to reproduce it.<ref>Huart, C., ''Les Calligraphes et les Miniaturistes de l'Orient Musulman'', 1972 p. 108 by [https://archive.org/details/lescalligraphes00huargoog Digital copy]</ref> While studying, he met [[Bayezid II|Bâyezïd]], the son of [[Mehmed the Conqueror|Sultan Mehmed, the Conqueror]] who was a fellow student, and the pair became friends. When Bâyezïd assumed the throne in 1481, following his father's death, he invited his friend, Sheikh Hamdullah, to the capital, Istanbul. Hamdullah went on to become a master calligrapher at the Imperial Palace.<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 46</ref>

In 1485, Bâyezïd II acquired seven works by the great calligrapher, [[Yaqut al-Musta'simi]]. Bâyezïd then encouraged his court calligrapher, Hamdullah, to devise a new script, inspired by the acquisition. Hamdullah regarded al-Musta'simi's work as unsurpassable, but at Bâyezïd's insistence, Hamdullah reluctantly agreed. Scholars have suggested that Bâyezïd's enthusiasm for a new script was symbolic of his desire to establish a new empire and a new dynasty.<ref>Özkafa, F., "İstanbul  ve  Hat  Sanatı" [Istanbul  and  the  Art  of  Calligraphy] in: Yusuf Çağlar (ed.), ''Bir Fotoğrafın Aynasında: İstanbul’un Meşhur Hattatları'' [Through the Mirror of a Picture: Eminent Calligraphers of Istanbul], Istanbul: İstanbul Büyükşehir Belediyesi, 2010, p. 114.</ref>

Hamdullah underwent a period of reclusion during which time he claimed that a prophet taught him the new scripts in a vision.<ref>Schimmel, A. Rivolta, B., "Islamic Calligraphy", ''Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin'',  vol. 50, no. 1, 1992, p. 21</ref> He ultimately recodified and refined the ''[[Naskh (script)|nashk]]'' style of calligraphy, originally developed by [[Yaqut al-Musta'simi]]. Hamdullah's scripts were more elegant, balanced and legible. From 1500, the majority of Q'rans adopted Hamdallah's new style, which became known as the ''Ottoman style'' or "Seyh's manner'. For this, he is often considered to be the "father of Ottoman calligraphy".<ref>Türk ve İslâm Eserleri Müzesi, ''The Art of the Qurʼan: Treasures from the Museum of Turkish and Islamic Arts'', Smithsonian Institution, 2016, p. 82</ref> His many students spread his style throughout the Ottoman Empire.<ref>Ülker, M. ''فن الخط التركي بين الماضي والحاضر'', (in Turkish and English), Türkiye İş Bankası Kültür, n.d., .p. 71</ref> His style endured for 150 years, making him one of the greatest Ottoman calligraphers of all time.<ref>M. Uğur Derman, ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'', N.Y., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 19</ref> As much as two centuries later, students of calligraphy such as [[Hâfiz Osman]] continued to copy his works assiduously as part of their training.<ref>Osborn, J.R., ''Letters of Light: Arabic Script in Calligraphy, Print, and Digital Design'', Harvard University Press, 2017, [E-book edition], n.p.</ref>

He devoted his whole life to the art of calligraphy, continuing to produce works well into his 80s. He produced 47 [[Mus'haf]]s, book of [[Quran]], and innumerable [[En'am]]s, [[Evrad]]s and [[Juz']], a number of which are held in the collection of the Topkapi Palace.<ref>Baydar and Hepworth, "Two Case Studies:The Rejoining of a Text-Block and the New Use of Remoistenable Tissue",  in: Driscoll, M.J. and Mósesdóttir, E. (eds), ''Care and Conservation of Manuscripts 11'', [Proceedings of the Eleventh International Seminar, University of Copenhagen, 24–25 April 2008], Museum Tusculanum Press, 2009, p. 135</ref> His inscriptions also decorate the Bâyezïd, Firuzaga and Davud Mosques in Istanbul and the Bâyezïd Mosque in Erdine.<ref>Dijkema, F.Th. (ed.),''The Ottoman Historical Monumental Inscriptions in Edirne'', BRILL, 1977, p. 45</ref>

His son, Mawlana Dede Chalabi, became a calligrapher after studying with Hamdallah (his father) and Hamdallah's  daughter, whose name is unknown, married a calligrapher by the name of Shukrullah Halife of Amasya, who had also been one of her father's pupils. Hamdullah's grandsons also became calligraphers; Pir Muhammad Dede (d. 986/1580, son of Hamdallah's daughter) and Dervish Muhammad (d. 888/1483, son of Mawlana Dede).<ref>Akin-Kivanc, E., ''Mustafa Âli's Epic Deeds of Artists: A Critical Edition of the Earliest Ottoman Text about the Calligraphers and Painters of the Islamic World, BRILL, 2011</ref>

As his reputation grew, many myths to his abilities outside calligraphy sprang up. It was said that he was a great archer, falconer, swimmer and even an extraordinary tailor.<ref>Huart, C., ''Les Calligraphes et les Miniaturistes de l'Orient Musulman'', 1972 p. 108 by [https://archive.org/details/lescalligraphes00huargoog Digital copy]</ref>

He died in Istanbul in 1520 and was buried at [[Karacaahmet Cemetery]] in the district of [[Üsküdar]] at [[Istanbul]]. Surviving examples of his works are held in the [[Topkapı Palace|Topkapi Collection]].<ref>''T Diez Albums: Contexts and Contents'', BRILL, c. 2016, p.136</ref>

<gallery>
File:Containing calligraphies ascribed to Şeyh Hamdullah - Murakka (calligraphic album) - Google Art Project (602085).jpg|Calligraphies ascribed to Şeyh Hamdullah from Murakka (calligraphic album)
File:Seyh Hamdullah - Page of Ottoman Calligraphy - Walters W6724A - Full Page.jpg|Page of Ottoman Calligraphy by Sheikh Hamdullah 
File:Seyh Hamdullah - Page of Pen Exercises - Walters W6725B - Full Page.jpg|Page of Pen Exercises by Sheikh Hamdullah 
</gallery>

==Legacy==
Biographical dictionaries outlining the lineages of calligraphers emerged as a small, but important literary genre in the 16th and 17th-centuries. In these works, a tradition of tracing an unbroken line of master-pupil relationships back to Sheikh Hamdullah, the man who was seen as the father of Ottoman calligraphy, is evident. These 'genealogies' continue to be published into the present.<ref>Behrens-Abouseif, D. and Vernoit, S., ''Islamic Art in the 19th Century: Tradition, Innovation, And Eclecticism'', BRILL, 2006, p.90-93; Khalili, N.D., ''Visions of Splendour in Islamic Art and Culture'', Worth Press Limited, 2008, p. 44; Auji, H., ''Printing Arab Modernity: Book Culture and The American Press in Nineteenth-Century Beirut'', BRILL, 2016, p. 27</ref>

Examples of these calligraphic genealogies include:
* [[Mustafa Âlî]], ''Epic Deeds of Artists,'' first published in 1587<ref>Akin-Kivanc, E., ''Mustafa Âli's Epic Deeds of Artists: A Critical Edition of the Earliest Ottoman Text about the Calligraphers and Painters of the Islamic World, BRILL, 2011, p.5</ref>
* Nefes-zade Ibrahim Efendi (d. 1650), ''Gülzâr-i Savâb'' [The Rose-garden of Proper Conduct], first published c. 1640<ref>Behrens-Abouseif, D. and Vernoit, S., ''Islamic Art in the 19th Century: Tradition, Innovation, And Eclecticism'', BRILL, 2006, p.90-91; Bayani, M., ''The Decorated Word: Qurʼans of the 17th to 19th Centuries,'' Volume 4, Part 1, Nour Foundation, 1999, p.66; Akin-Kivanc, E., ''Mustafa Âli's Epic Deeds of Artists: A Critical Edition of the Earliest Ottoman Text about the Calligraphers and Painters of the Islamic World, BRILL, 2011, p.10. It may be worth noting that a republished edition of the original appeared in 1938, edited by Kilisli Muallim Rifat</ref>
* Sayocluzâde Mehmed Necîb (d. 1757), ''Devhatü’l-küttâb'' (دوحة الكتّاب) [Genealogy of the Scribes, sometimes translated as the Great Tree of Penmen], first published c. 1737 <ref>Behrens-Abouseif, D. and Vernoit, S., ''Islamic Art in the 19th Century: Tradition, Innovation, And Eclecticism'', BRILL, 2006, p.90-93; Bayani, M., ''The Decorated Word: Qurʼans of the 17th to 19th Centuries,'' Volume 4, Part 1, Nour Foundation, 1999, p.66; Akin-Kivanc, E., ''Mustafa Âli's Epic Deeds of Artists: A Critical Edition of the Earliest Ottoman Text about the Calligraphers and Painters of the Islamic World, BRILL, 2011, p.10. It may be worth noting that the original was republished in a 1939 edition, edited by Kilisli Muallim Rifat and published in Istanbul.</ref>
* Müstakim-zade Süleyman Sa'deddin Efendi, ''Tuhfei Hattatin'' [Present for Calligraphers or sometimes translated as Choice Gift for Calligraphers], first published c. 1788  <ref>Behrens-Abouseif, D. and Vernoit, S., ''Islamic Art in the 19th Century: Tradition, Innovation, And Eclecticism'', BRILL, 2006, p.91; Akin-Kivanc, E., ''Mustafa Âli's Epic Deeds of Artists: A Critical Edition of the Earliest Ottoman Text about the Calligraphers and Painters of the Islamic World, BRILL, 2011, p.11.</ref>
* "The Genealogy of Ottoman Calligraphers" in: M. Uğur Derman (ed.), ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' New York, Harry Abrams, 2010, pp 186–189

pages.title: Suyolcuzade Mustafa Eyyubi
pages.text:
[[File:Suyolcuzade Mustafa Eyyubi - Kıta, Hadis-i Şerifler.jpg|thumb|right|An undated kit'a with one line written in [[Thuluth]] and two lines in [[Naskh (script)|Naskh]]]]
'''Suyolcuzade Mustafa Eyyubi''' (1619?, Istanbul - 1686) was a 17th-century [[Ottoman Turks|Ottoman]] [[calligrapher]]. 

==Life and work==
Suyolcuzade Mustafa Eyyubi was born in the Eyiib district of Istanbul in around 1619. He was the son of Suyolcu Ömer Ağa.<ref>''Islamic Encyclopedia,'' [http://www.islamansiklopedisi.info/dia/ayrmetin.php?idno=380002 Online:]</ref>

Initially, he studied calligraphy with Dede, who was very elderly at the time, and known as the "grandfather". Following the master's death, Eyyubi studied with [[Derviş Ali]].<ref>Kemal Çiçek, Ercüment Kuran, Nejat Göyünç, İlber Ortaylı, ''The Great Ottoman-Turkish Civilisation,'' Volume 3, Yeni Türkiye, 2000, n.p.; ''Islamic Encyclopedia,'' [http://www.islamansiklopedisi.info/dia/ayrmetin.php?idno=380002 Online:]</ref> 

Some of his best known students are Cabizade Abdullah, [[Hâfiz Osman]] and Hocazade Mehmed.<ref>{{cite book| author = M. Uğur Derman| title = Masterpieces of Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Museum| publisher=Sabancı Üniversitesi|location=İstanbul |year = 2004| isbn = 978-975-8362-45-5 | pages = 82–83 }}</ref><ref>Kemal Çiçek, Ercüment Kuran, Nejat Göyünç, İlber Ortaylı, ''The Great Ottoman-Turkish Civilisation,'' Volume 3, Yeni Türkiye, 2000, n.p.</ref>

Few of his works have survived. From about fifty Qur'an and 100 ''An'am-i Sharif'' written by him, just a few are available today.<ref>Karadaş, Celalettin. «Suyolcuzade Mustafa Eyyubi'nin Mushafı». Güzel Sanatlar Enstitüsü Dergisi (Erzurum: Atatürk Üniversitesi) 21 (2008): 113-121.</ref> He also produced 100 ''en'am'' and various ''qit'at''. <ref>Pickthall, M. W. and Asad, M., ''Islamic Culture,'' Volume 57, Islamic Culture Board, 1983, p. 20</ref> Some of the surviving works are held in the [[Topkapı Palace|Topkapi Collection]].<ref>''The Diez Albums: Contexts and Contents'', BRILL, c. 2016, p.136</ref>

He died in 1686 in and was buried in the Kabristani in the Hamamarkası at Eyüp, but the location of his tomb is not known. The grave inscriptions were written by his grandson, Suyolcuzâde Mehmed Necib (d. 1757), who was also a calligrapher. <ref>''Islamic Encyclopedia,'' [http://www.islamansiklopedisi.info/dia/ayrmetin.php?idno=380002 Online:]</ref> His grandson, Suyolcuzâde Mehmed Necib, wrote the ''Devḥatü l-küttāb'', [translated as Genealogy of the Scribes or the Great Tree of Penmen] a compilation of biographies of famous calligraphers.<ref>''Islamic Encyclopedia,'' [http://www.islamansiklopedisi.info/dia/ayrmetin.php?idno=380002 Online (in Turkish); Behrens-Abouseif, D. and Vernoit, S., ''Islamic Art in the 19th Century: Tradition, Innovation, And Eclecticism'', BRILL, 2006, p.90-93; Bayani, M., ''The Decorated Word: Qurʼans of the 17th to 19th Centuries,'' Volume 4, Part 1, Nour Foundation, 1999, p.66; Akin-Kivanc, E., ''Mustafa Âli's Epic Deeds of Artists: A Critical Edition of the Earliest Ottoman Text about the Calligraphers and Painters of the Islamic World, BRILL, 2011, p.10.</ref>

pages.title: Yedikuleli Seyyid 'Abdullah Efendi
pages.text:
[[File:Copied by Yedikuleli Seyyid Abdullah Efendi - Kıt’a (single piece) - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|Kıt'a (single piece) by Yedikuleli Seyyid Abdullah Efendi]]
'''Yedikuleli Seyyid Abdullah Efendi''' ({{lang-ota| يدى قللى سيد ابدالله}} [[Turkish language|Modern Turkish]]: ''Yedikuleli Seyyid Abdullah Efendi'') (1670-1731) was an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] master [[calligraphy|calligrapher]].

==Life and career==
Born Hâşimîzâde Abdullah Efendi in 1670 in Istanbul, his father was Sayyid Hassan al-Hashimite, the imam of Imrahor Mosque.<ref>''Islam Encyclopedia'', [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/abdullah-efendi-hasimizade Online:]</ref> He was born into a family of calligraphers and grew up in the 'Yedikuleli' district from which he derived the nickname. He was descended from the prophet, Mohammed through both his paternal and maternal line, which allowed him to use the title of Seyyid. He studied calligraphy with the great master, [[Hâfiz Osman]].<ref>Uğur Derman, M., ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998 , p. 78; Sothey'ss Auctions, [http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2017/arts-of-the-islamic-world-l17220/lot.72.html Online:]</ref>

He became a court calligrapher and was a favourite of [[Ahmed III|Sultan Ahmed III]]. He was appointed as the instructor of calligraphy at the [[Topkapı Palace|Topkapi]] Palace in 1708, where he taught [[Egrikapili Mehmed Rasim Efendi]]. He wrote many copies of the [[Qur'an]].<ref>Safwat, N.F., ''Understanding Calligraphy: The Ottoman Contribution'', Part One, London, 2014, p.322</ref>

At one point Ahmed III was so intrigued by the ink that Seyyid used in his calligraphy, that he sent a messenger to learn the secret. Seyyid sent back a full inkwell with the messenger. When the Sultan received the gift, he reportedly emptied the ink, refilled the inkwell with gold, and sent it back.<ref name="ref1">{{cite web|url=http://warandpeaceinthemiddleeast.com/2011/10/arabic-script-transformed-by-ottoman-calligraphers|title=Stories of Ottoman Calligraphers|accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref>

pages.title: Mehmed Esad Yesari
pages.text:
'''Mehmed Esad Yesari''' ([[Turkish language|Modern Turkish]]: ''Mehmet Es'ad Yesârî'') (died 1798) (alternative names: Asad Yasārī, Taliknüvis Mehmed al-Assad, Şeyhülislam Veliyüddin Efendi) was an 18th-century [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[calligrapher]] known as the greatest calligrapher of his age.

==Life and work==
Mehmed Esad Yesari was born in Istanbul, the son of Kara Mahmud Aga, bailiff to the Grand Judge of Anatolia.<ref> Huart, C., ''Les Calligraphes et les Miniaturistes de l'Orient Musulman''  1972, p. 291 [https://archive.org/details/lescalligraphes00huargoog Digital copy (in French)]</ref> Born paralyzed on the right side of his body, he was given the nickname ''Yesari'', meaning left-handed.<ref>Bloom, J. and Blair, S.S., ''Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art & Architecture, Oxford University Press, 2009, Vol. 1, p. 446; İhsanoğlu, E., ''Culture and Learning in Islam'', UNESCO, 2003, p. 583</ref> 

He began his training with Seyhulislam Veliuddin (d.1768), but was turned away due to his poor condition. He then studied with Dedezade Mehmed Efendi (d.1758) who almost immediately recognised his talent. He was very frail and small. Due to his weakness he was carried from room to room in a custom-designed basket.<ref>M. Uğur Derman, ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'', N.Y., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 100</ref>

He was a master of the ''[[Taʿlīq script|ta'liq]]'' script who made improvements to it and created works of great beauty.<ref>Pickthall, M.W. and Asad, M., ''Islamic Culture,'' Volume 57, Islamic Culture Board, 1983, p. 22</ref> Early in his career, he followed the ''ta'liq'' style of the Persian master, [[Mir Emad Hassani]]. However, as he matured, he developed his own style by incorporating Persian elements with his own. This style, which ultimately became the 'Ottoman style' (''[[Nastaʿlīq script|nesta'lik]]''), was later refined by his son, to the extent that it eclipsed the Persian original.<ref>M. Uğur Derman, ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'', N.Y., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 20; İhsanoğlu, E., ''Culture and Learning in Islam'', UNESCO, 2003, p. 583</ref> 

He served at the Imperial Palace of Sultan Mustafa III, where he produced many architectural monuments commissioned by the Sultan.<ref>M. Uğur Derman, ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'', N.Y., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 100</ref> He produced a number of ''kit'alar'', ''muralaakar'' and ''levhar''. He also produced inscriptions such as for Sultan Mehmet II's tomb, the Haci Selim Aga Library in Uskudar, the Beylerbeyi Mosque and inside the Barracks of the Black Eunechs (inside the harem); all of which exhibit the finest examples of  ''ta'liq'' script.<ref>M. Uğur Derman, ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'', N.Y., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 100</ref>

His son and his pupil [[Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet Efendi|Yasarizade Mustafa 'Izzet]] (d. 1265/1849) also became a calligrapher of some note.<ref name="ref1">{{cite web|url=http://kalemguzeli.org/index.php?go=main&KNO=15|title="Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet Efendi" [Brief Biography] (translated from Turkish)}}</ref> Other notable students included Mehmet Sehabeddin and Mir Emin (1758-1809).

His son took Yesari on a pilgrimage to Mecca in 1792. After that, his condition worsened and he died on 19 December, 1798. He was buried at a cemetery in the Gelenbevi section at the Fatih district of Istanbul.<ref>M. Uğur Derman, ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'', N.Y., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 100</ref>

pages.title: Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet Efendi
pages.text:
[[File:Hilye Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet Efendi.JPG|thumb|[[Hilya]] by Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet Efendi, gilded panel with [[nastaʿlīq script]], [[Mevlana Museum]]]]
'''Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet  Efendi''' ([[Turkish language|Modern Turkish]]: ''Yesârîzâde Mustafa Izzet Efendi'') (d. 1849) was an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[calligraphy|calligrapher]].<ref name="Tuğlacı1990">{{cite book|last=Tuğlacı|first=Pars|title=The role of the Balian family in Ottoman architecture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=btTVAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=17 December 2011|year=1990|publisher=Yeni Çığır Bookstore}}</ref>

==Life and work==
Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet Efendi's date of birth is not known, but is assumed to be in the 1780s. He was born in [[Istanbul]] and was the son of the calligrapher, [[Mehmed Esad Yesari]].<ref>''Islam Encyclopedia'', [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/mustafa-izzet-yesarizade Online:]</ref>

After studying calligraphy with his father, he served as a [[Kazasker]] of [[Rumelia]]. Mustafa became a well known calligrapher in his own right, and taught students at the Imperial Court.<ref name="ref1">{{cite web|url=http://kalemguzeli.org/index.php?go=main&KNO=15|title=Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet Efendi Brief Biography (Turkish)|accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref>

His father had developed a unique style of ''[[Taʿlīq script|ta'liq]]'' script called ''[[Nastaʿlīq script|nesta'lik]]'', which was based on elements from the Persian master, [[Mir Emad Hassani]] combined with  stylistic elements developed by Mehmed Esad Yesari (Yesarizade's father).<ref>M. Uğur Derman, ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'', N.Y., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 20</ref> Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet built on changes made by his father, making further improvements and elaborating the rules for the method. This new style was called ''celî ta'liq'' and was much better suited to Ottoman tastes. His version of the script remains largely unchanged and has been passed down to the modern day <ref>Mülayim, S. and Akşit, O., ''Turkish Art and Architecture in Anatolia & Mimar Sinan'', Akşit, 2005, p. 262; M. Uğur Derman, ''Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul'', N.Y., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998, p. 20</ref>

He died on 23 June 1849 and was buried near the Fâtih madrasah, next to his father. Their graves were moved following a fire in the district.<ref>''Islam Encyclopedia'', [https://islamansiklopedisi.org.tr/mustafa-izzet-yesarizade Online:]</ref>

'''Qorban Ali Ajalli Vaseq''' ({{lang-fa|قربانعلی اجلی واثق}}; pen name, '''Vassegh'''; born February 8, 1939) is a master calligrapher, painter, poet and educator, noted for founding the "Gol Gasht" style of [[calligraphy]], characterised by a dense and interlocking play of the [[Arabic script]], a distinctive style now regularly used by Arab and [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] calligraphers in artworks.

==Life and career==
Ali Adjalli was born in [[Mianeh, Iran]], on February 8, 1939. He was the son of Mohammed Ali, a Turkish calligraphy poet and a former pupil of calligrapher, Professor Seyed Hossein Mirkhani (1907–1982). His mother taught the [[Quran|Q'ran]] at Ferdowsi Elementary School and High School.<ref>"Gulgasht's Pedagogue", in: ''The Voice of Miyana'', [http://www.voiceofmiyana.ir/msnaebi/50 Online:] (translated from Persian)</ref>

He attended the Ferdowsi Elementary School and Pahlavi Middle High School and graduated from the Iranian Razi High School in Tehran. He received his initial arts education at [[Tehran]]’s Lycée Français, following that with a Masters' Degree in [[Architectural Engineering]] from Tehran's College of Design in 1960. Returning to his childhood love of painting, Adjalli then studied calligraphy and calligraphic painting under the direction of Professor Ibrahim Bouzari and Professor Ahmad Najafi Zanjani amongst others.<ref>"Gulgasht's Pedagogue", in: ''The Voice of Miyana'', [http://www.voiceofmiyana.ir/msnaebi/50 Online:] (translated from Persian)</ref>

Shortly after completing his studies, Adjalli developed a new style of calligraphy which he called ''Gol Gasht'',<ref>[https://www.noormags.ir/view/fa/articlepage/1038/48/text]</ref><ref>http://www.magiran.com/ppdf/nppdf/2387/p0238706930331.pdf</ref><ref>Jamm Art & Beyond, ''Contemporary Art Auction'', [Auction Catalogue], 2010, n.p., [https://ansam518.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/jamm_auction_catalogue.pdf Online:]</ref> characterised by dense, interlocking style of Arabic script intended for use in painting rather than manuscripts. The script has been described as both "mesmerising and chaotic".<ref>Aossey, D.W., "Drawing Conclusions: Shedding a Vital Light on Middle Eastern Art", [Review of S. Eigner's book], ''Art of the Middle East: Modern and Contemporary Art of the Arab World and Iran'' Merrell, 2010] in: ''Al Jadid'', vol. 16, no. 62, 2010 [https://www.aljadid.com/content/drawing-conclusions-shedding-vital-light-middle-eastern-art Online:]</ref>

Apart from his work as an artist and poet (writing under the pen name of Vassegh), he began a career as an educator in 1974, becoming a university lecturer on [[fine arts]], and then Master of Calligraphy at numerous institutions including the prestigious ''Calligraphy Academy of Iran''.

==Work==
His paintings are inspired by his interests in scripture, spiritual poetry and Islamic architecture. He primarily uses acrylic on canvas an applies the medium in thick layers, painting and re-painting over each form until he achieves the desired look and feel. He consciously uses colours selected from the Islamic palette.<ref>Jamm Art & Beyond, ''Contemporary Art Auction'', [Auction Catalogue], 2010, n.p., [https://ansam518.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/jamm_auction_catalogue.pdf Online:]</ref> His works combine non-figurative representation and abstraction.<ref>van der Velden, F., Behr, H.H. and Haußmann, G. (eds), ''das Licht aus der Nische holen: Kompetenzorientierung im christlichen und islamischen Religionsunterricht der Kollegstufe, Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 2013, p. 72</ref>

Adjalli has exhibited his works at a number of international institutions and galleries,<ref>"Ali Adjalli" [Biographical Notes] in: Opera Gallery, ''Arabesque'', [Illustrated Exhibition Catalogue], Beirut, Opera Gallery, n.d., p. 12</ref> including solo exhibitions at the [[Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art]] and at the [[Niavaran Palace Complex|Niavaran Palace Institute]] and group exhibitions in Sydney, Australia (2012);<ref>The ''Iranian Contemporary Art'', July 5 – August 4, 2012 at the New Albion Gallery, See: ''Iran News'', February 7, 2012, [http://www.payvand.com/news/12/jul/1015.html Online:]</ref> Abu Dhabi (2010);<ref>"Get the lowdown on The Abu Dhabi art fair at Emirate's Palace", ''Time Out'', October 26, 2010, [https://www.timeoutabudhabi.com/art/features/18766-abu-dhabi-art Online:]</ref> Dubai (2010), Bahrain (2010)<ref>Common Threads Exhition at NM Art Gallery, March 10 -April 16, 2010, Heritage House, Bastakiya, Dubai See: [http://www.artbahrain.org/archives/mar2011/artnews_preview_dubai2_mar.php Art Bahrain]</ref> and Rome (2016)<ref>Oriental Art, Museum of Oriental Arts, Rome, March 23 – April 30, 2016; See: "Art Exhibition of Iran at the Museum of Oriental Arts in Rome", ''ANA'' [http://www.ana.ir/news/2164318 April, 1394 (2016)] (translated from Persian)</ref>

The bulk of his Adjalli's work is now held in private collections.<ref>"Ali Adjalli" [Biographical Notes] in: Opera Gallery, ''Arabesque'', [Illustrated Exhibition Catalogue], Beirut, Opera Gallery, n.d., p. 12</ref> However, examples of his work can be found in the permanent collection of the Tehran Gallery.

pages.title: Ahmad Mashhadi
pages.text:
'''Ahmad Mashhadi''', also known as '''Mir Seyyed Ahmad''', was an important [[Persian people|Persian]] [[Nastaliq]] [[calligrapher]] in the 16th century. He was from [[Mashhad]]. He was also a [[poet]] and some of his original poems still exist.<ref>{{citation|surname1=Habibollah Fazaeli|title=Atlas-e-Chat(Calligraphy Atlas) |publisher=Mashal|pages=479–482|isbn=978-964-376-649-8|date=  1983|language=Persian}}</ref>

== Biography ==
Mashhadi learnt calligraphy art in [[Herat]] under [[Mir Ali Heravi]]. After that [[Shaybanids]] captured the city, both of them immigrated to [[Bukhara]]. After Heravi's death, he worked some time as a [[scrivener]] in the [[library]] of Abdolaziz Khan Ozbak. When Abdolaziz Khan died, he came back to his home town. He worked there as a scrivener in the court of [[Tahmasp I]] and his successor [[Ismail II]]. He died in 1578 in [[Mazandaran]].<ref>{{citation|surname1=Habibollah Fazaeli|title=Atlas-e-Chat( |publisher=Mashal|pages=482|isbn=978-964-376-649-8|date=  1983|language=Persian}}</ref>

pages.title: Ahmad Monshi Ghomi
pages.text:
'''Ahmad Monshi Ghomi''', also known as '''Ghazi Ahmad''', was a [[Persian people|Persian]]<ref name="Donzel1994">{{cite book|last1=Donzel|first1=E. J. van|title=Islamic Desk Reference|date=1 January 1994|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-09738-4|page=364|quote=Qum(m)i, Qadi Ahmad Ibrahim Husayni: Persian chronicler and chancery clerk; 1546-?. He wrote a chronicle in five volumes, of which the fifth volume only has been preserved. It describes the history of the Safawids down to the first years of Shah Abbas * I. He is also the author of a treatise on calligraphers and painters.}}</ref> [[author]] and [[calligrapher]]. He was the son of ''Sharaf ed-Din Hossein Ghomi'', who was the [[scrivener]] of [[Sam Mirza Safavi]] in [[Herat]]. Ghazi Ahmad was born in 1547 in [[Qom]]. When he was 11 years old, he moved with his father to [[Mashhad]] and spent 20 years in that city. Under protection of ''Soltan Abolfath Ebrahim Mirza'', he took lessons from the famous masters like ''Shah Mahmoud Neishabouri'', Mir [[Ahmad Mashhadi]] and [[Malek Deylami]] until the age of 31. Ebrahim Mirza was a well-educated man in the field of [[art]] and [[science]] and some of prominent [[poet]]s, [[calligrapher]]s and [[painter]]s worked in his [[library]]. Ghazi Ahmad spent his youth in the art circles of Ebrahim Mirza's court. He had also relations with many painting and calligraphy masters out of Ebrahim mirza's library and because of this he could recounted many details about the artists' lives in the [[Safavid]] era. His works, [[Golestan-e Honar]], introduces artists, whom he knew personally or knew about them by other trusted persons. He has other books like ''Kholassat ot-Tavarikh'', which is the history of Safavid dynasty from [[Safi-ad-din Ardabili]] to the early period of [[Abbas I of Persia|Abbas I]], and also ''Majma osh-Shoara'' and ''Managheb of-Fozala''. In 1599, Abbas I got angry at Ghazi Ahmad and ordered his dismissal. After he was dismissed he went to Ghom. In 1607, he met ''Molana Mohammad Amir Aghili Rostamdari Ardebili'', who was a well-known calligrapher in that time. Ghazi Ahmad wrote about him in Golestan-e Honar.<ref>{{citation
|surname1=Habibollah Fazaeli
|title=Atlas e Xat(Calligraphy Atlas) 
|publisher=Mashal
|pages=482
|date=  1983
}}</ref>

pages.title: Sultan Ali Mashhadi
pages.text:
[[File:Sultan Ali al-Mashhadi - Album of Persian Miniatures and Calligraphy - Walters W671 - Top Exterior.jpg|thumb|''Album of Persian Miniatures and Calligraphy'', Sultan Ali Mashhadi contributor, [[Walters Art Museum]]]]
{{Commons category}}
'''Sultan Ali Mashhadi''' (1453-1520) was a  Persian calligrapher and poet.

==Education and career==
Sultan Ali was born in [[Mashhad]] in 1453, and was orphaned at an early age. He was an [[Autodidacticism|autodidact]] and was later trained by [[Maulana Azhar|Azhar]] ([[floruit|fl.]] 1421-72), or by one of Azhar's students. 

From 1470 to 1506 Sultan Ali worked at the [[Timurid dynasty|Timurid]] court in [[Herat]] for the royal author Sultan [[Husayn Bayqarah]] (1438–1506). His calligraphy primarily used the [[Nastaʿlīq script]]. He was also a poet.<ref name="ref1">{{cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/55.121.10.32|title=Sultan Ali Mashhadi Brief Biography|accessdate=2012-07-19}}</ref> He died in Mashhad in 1520.

pages.title: Ali Reza Abbassi
pages.text:
[[File:AliReza Abbasi1.JPG|thumb|A [[Chalipa]] in [[Nastaʿlīq script]] by Ali Reza Abbassi]]
'''Alireza Abbassi Tabrizi''' was a prominent [[Iran]]ian [[calligrapher]] and [[calligraphy]] teacher. He was titled by [[Abbas I of Persia|Abbas I]] as ''Šāhnavāz Xān''. Abbassi was a master of [[Naskh (script)|Naskh]] and [[Thuluth]] scripts and the initiator of his own style of [[Nastaʿlīq script|Nastaʿlīq]] script. Besides he was an expert of various other scripts like [[Muhaqqaq]], [[Reqa]], [[Reyhan (script)|Reyhan]], [[Tevki]] and [[Taʿlīq script]]s.<ref>Mohammad Naghshi Tabrizi: Hayāt e Alireza Abbassi, Xošnevis e maruf e dore ye Safaviye (The life of Ali Reza Abbassi, the famous calligrapher in the Safavid era). In: Honar o Mardom(Art and People). volume 2, Nr. 20, 1964, S. 30–31.</ref>

== Youth ==
Ali Reza Abbassi started learning calligraphy in [[Tabriz]] as a pupil of [[Mohammad Hossein Tabrizi]] and [[Alaeddin Tabrizi|Ala Beyk]]. Abbassi obtained an outstanding knowledge of Thuluth and Naskh scripts. After that the [[Ottomans]] occupied Tabriz in the era of [[Mohammad Khodabanda]], Abbassi left the city and went to [[Qazvin]], the capital of the [[Safavid dynasty]]. He lived there in the [[Jameh Mosque of Qazvin|Jameh mosque of Qazvin]]. He worked as a calligrapher and completed some parts of [[inscription]]s of the mosque and also some [[Koran]] samples. His works on the Jameh mosque of Qazvin made him famous. In the early years of the reign of Abbas I, he was in Farhad Khan's employ, who was an important [[Sardar]] of the Safavids and his rank and dignity was increasing under Abbass I. When Sardar Farhad Khan noticed that Alireza Abbassi was an able artist, he appointed him as his personal companion and took Abbassi as his companion to [[Greater Khorasan|Khorasan]] and [[Mazandaran Province|Mazandaran]].<ref>http://rahnamaei-honar.blogsky.com/1390/10</ref> 

== In the court of Safavids ==
Alireza Abbassi's fame increased. On the 1st of July 1593 Abbassi became the King's intimate friend and the King instructed some of calligraphers like [[Mohammad Reza Emami]], [[Mohammad Saleh Esfahani]] and [[Abd ol-Baghi Tabrizi]] to teach Abbassi Thuluth script.<ref>http://xyz200875.blogfa.com/post/4</ref>

Abbassi's death date in unknown, but it is supposed that he died towards the end of [[Safi of Persia|Safi]]'s era.

{{lang|fa|{{nq|بابا شاه اصفهانی}}}} | honorific_suffix = | image = Baba Shah Isfahani (Frontispiece) - Malek National Library and Museum Institution, Iran.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = Sheikh Muslih-Uddin Sa'di Shiraz, copied by Baba Shah Isfahani, placed at Malek National Library and Museum Institution, Tehran, Iran. | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Isfahan]], [[Iran]] | death_date = | death_place = [[Baghdad]], [[Iraq]] | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = [[Calligraphy]] | notable_works = The Spirit of Islamic Calligraphy: Ādāb al-mashq
Benefits of Calligraphy | style = | home_town = | movement = | spouse = | partner = | awards = Master of Masters
Reyis or-Roassa | patrons = [[Shah Tahmasp I]] }} '''Baba Shah Isfahani''' ({{lang-fa|{{nastaliq|بابا شاه اصفهانی}}}}, ''Bābā Šāh Isfahāni''), also known as '''Baba Shah Araghi''' ({{lang|fa|{{nastaliq|بابا شاه عراقی}}}}, ''Bābā Šāh Arāqi''), was the most famous [[Iran]]ian [[calligrapher]] in the 16th century and the most prominent calligrapher of [[Nastaliq]] script in the era of [[Tahmasp I]]. He was titled as ''Reyis or-Roassa''. His calligraphy teacher was [[Ahmad Mashhadi]]. In 1588, when he was young, he ravelled to [[Iraq]]. He was killed in [[Baghdad]] and was buried in this city. His works date back from 1569 until 1586.{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopaediaislamica.com/|title=encyclopaediaislamica.com|website=www.encyclopaediaislamica.com}}{{citation|title=Atlas-e-Chat(Calligraphy Atlas)|pages=492–494|year=1983|publisher=Mashal|isbn=978-964-376-649-8|surname1=Habibollah Fazaeli}}
{{Orphan|date=September 2016}} = Early Life = [[File:Amir Khosru Dehlavi's Masnavi-e Davalrāni Khezar Khān, 1590 CE, Astān-e Qods Razavi Library, No. 10519.png|thumb|alt=|Amir Khosru Dehlavi's Masnavi-e Davalirani Khezar Khan, '''Copied by the master scribe Baba Shah al-Isfahani, [[Central Library of Astan Quds Razavi]]''']]On the report of some "modern authorities like the Turkish scholar Habib Effendi, Baba Shah Isfahani had begun the study of calligraphy from the age of eight, and studied night and day for eight years with the celebrated [[Mir Ali Heravi|Mir 'Ali Haravi]] (d. 951/1544-45), who perfected the [[nasta'liq]] style in [[Herat]] and [[Bukhara]]. Habib Effendi further states that [[Mir Emad Hassani|Mir Emad]] (d. 1012/1603), perhaps the most admired master of [[nastaliq]], derived his style from Baba Shah.Habib Efendi, Khatt wa Khattdtdn ([[Constantinople]], 1305), in Shafi', 239. If correct, this information would put Baba Shah's birth at least sixteen years before [[Mir Ali Heravi|Mir 'Ali's]] death, or no later than 940/1533-34Although Baba Shah Isfahani quotes the poetry of [[Mir Ali Heravi|Mir 'Ali Haravi]] (Adab al-mashq, 268), we cannot be certain that he was a student of the latter. [[Mir Ali Heravi|Mir 'Ali Haravi's]] date of death has been put anywhere from 924/1518 to 976/1568, but the date of 951/1544 is found in a contemporary tazkira written in [[Herat]], Muzakkir-i Ahbab by Ilasan "Nisari"; cf. Muhammad Bakhtavar Khan, Mira't al-'alam, tarikh-i Awrangzib, ed. Sajida S. Alvi, Publication of the Research Society of Pakistan, no. 55 (Lahore: Research Society of Pakistan, 1979), 11:477, n. 1.. On the other hand, Muhammad Qutb al-Din Yazdi wrote that he had met Baba Shah Isfahani in 995/1586-87, when the latter was still a young man, and he was amazed to see that he already excelled most of the calligraphers of the day. Qutb al-Din said that if he had lived longer, Baba Shah would have surpassed [[Sultan Ali Mashhadi|Sultan 'Ali Mashhadi]] and [[Mir Ali Heravi|Mir 'Ali Haravi]], and to achieve so much he must have had a divine giftMuhammad Qutb al-Din Yazdi, Risdla-i Qutbiyya, in Shafic, 249.. This information obviously conflicts with the statement of Habib Effendi, according to whom Baba Shah would have been over fifty at the very time when Qutb al-DIn commented on his youth; Qutb al-Din's statement also implies that Baba Shah died young, before realizing his full potential. Following the researches of the modern Iranian scholar Mehdi Bayani, we should accept the eyewitness account of Qutb al-Din, so that Baba Shah must have died in [[Baghdad]] in 996/1587-88; the modern attempt to link Baba Shah into the chain of the two greatest masters of nasta'liq cannot be demonstratedBaydni, 1:86. 'Ali Efendi's report that Baba Shah was the student of Mir 'Ali's best pupil, [[Ahmad Mashhadi|Sayyid Ahmad Mashhadi]] (d. 986/1578-79), also appears unlikely, since Baba Shah seems never to have left Isfahan (ibid., 46).."[https://www.jstor.org/stable/603706?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents Journal of the American Oriental Society, Vol. 112, No. 2 (Apr. - Jun., 1992), pp. 279-286] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:People from Isfahan]] [[Category:Iranian calligraphers]] [[Category:1500s births]] [[Category:16th-century people of the Safavid Empire]] [[Category:16th-century Iranian people]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:Persian calligraphy]]

pages.title: Malek Deylami
pages.text:
'''Molana Malek Deylami''' (1518 in [[Qazvin]] - 1562 in [[Qazvin]]) was a [[Persian people|Persian]] [[scrivener]] and [[calligrapher]] in the 16th century.<ref>{{citation
|surname1=Mehdi Bayani Yassavoli
|title=Ahvâl o Âsâr e Xošnevisân (The Calligrapher's Biographies and Works) 
|publisher=Elmi

|pages=598–609
|date=  1966
|language=Persian
}}</ref> He was a skillful [[Nastaliq]] calligrapher, who wrote bold and fine script skillfully.<ref>{{citation
|surname1=Javad Yassavoli
|title=Peydâyeš o Seyr e Tahavvol e Honar e Xat (The origin and developing process of the calligraphy) 
|publisher=Yassavoli

|pages=143
|date=  1981
|language=Persian
}}</ref>

== Biography ==
His first teacher was his father ''Shohreh Amir'', who taught him [[Thuluth]] and [[Naskh (script)|Naskh]].<ref>{{citation
|author=Ḥabībollāh Fażāʾelī
|title=Aṭlas-e Ḫaṭṭ: Taḥqīq dar Ḫuṭūṭ-e Islāmī |trans-title=Research in the Islamic scripts
|location=Isfahan
|pages=484
|date=1971–72
|language=Persian
}}</ref> Later, when [[Rostam Ali Khorassani]] and ''Hafez Baba Jan'' went to Qazvin, he learnt Nastaliq from them. It is said that Malek Deilami was a student of [[Mir Ali Heravi]] or at least he drilled a lot from Heravi's works.
Molana Malek was the teacher of the [[Safavid]] prince, [[Ibrahim Mirza|Abolfazl Soltan Ibrahim Mirza]]. Ibrahim Mirza, who was [[Bahram Mirza]]'s son and [[Sam Mirza]]'s nephew, was an art lover from the house of Safavids. He was not an ambitious man and because of it he was favorite of [[Tahmasp I]]. Ibrahim Mirza married to the [[Tahmasp I|Shah]]'s daughter, ''Gohar Solatn'', in 1556. He was appointed governor of [[Mashhad]], where was the living and burial place of his father. He took Molana Malek as the [[painting]] teacher and curator of his library to Mashhad, but after 3 or 4 years he was called back to Qazvin by Tahmasp I for writing and inscription on the new royal building. This event shouldn't be later than 1561. In this time, he was writing the manuscript of [[Jami]]'s [[Haft Awrang]], which became one of the most famous manuscripts. This manuscript is kept in [[Freer Gallery of Art]] in [[Washington D. C.]]. Writing this book with its 28 [[Persian miniature|miniature]]s took 9 years and Deylami's successors like [[Moheb Ali Neynavaz Heravi]], [[Rostam Ali Khorssani|Rostam Ali]] and [[Molana Eyshi Heravi]] and [[Shah Mahmoud Neishabouri]] finished the calligraphy of the book.<ref>{{citation
|author=[[Basil Gray]]
|title=Persian Paintings
|pages=124–125
|date=1977
}}</ref> Malek was the companion of the Safavid Shah in Qazvin until death and he was buried in this city.

== His students ==
[[Mir Emad]], the greatest Nastaliq calligrapher in the history, learnt Nastaliq from Malek Deylami for a while.

His other notable students were as follows:
* [[Mohammad Hossein Tabrizi]]
* Shah Mohammad Mashhadi
* [[Molana Eyshi Heravi]]
* Ghotb ed-Din Yazdi
* [[Ibrahim Mirza|Soltan Ibrahim Mirza]]
* Mir Sadr ed-Din Mohammad<ref>{{citation
|surname1=Javad Yassavoli
|title=Peydâyeš o Seyr e Tahavvol e Honar e Xat (The origin and developing process of the calligraphy) 
|publisher=Yassavoli

|pages=149
|date=  1981
|language=Persian
}}</ref>

pages.title: Mohammad Mohsen Emami
pages.text:
'''Mohammad Mohsen Emami''' was a famous [[Persian people|Persian]] [[calligrapher]] of the [[Thuluth]] script in the [[Safavid]] era. He was [[Mohammad Reza Emami]]'s son and [[Ali Naghi Emami]]'s father, who were also the famous calligrapher of the Thuluth script.

Many [[inscription]]s of Mohammad Mohsen Emami still exist on the historical buildings of [[Isfahan]]. Although Emami was very skillful in [[Nastaliq]] and [[Naskh (script)|Naskh]], but he is mostly famous for his Thuluth works. He lived in the era of [[Suleiman I of Persia|Suleiman I]] and [[Sultan Husayn]].<ref>{{citation

pages.title: Aboutorab Esfahani
pages.text:
'''Aboutorab Esfahani''', [[pseudonym]]: Toraba, (1581–1662) was a prominent [[Persian people|Persian]] [[calligrapher]] of the [[Nastaliq]] script and one of the most important calligraphy students of [[Mir Emad]].<ref>{{citation|surname1=Ḥabībollāh Fażāʾelī|title=Aṭlas-e Ḫaṭṭ : Taḥqīq dar Ḫuṭūṭ-e Islāmī (Research in the Islamic scripts)|publication-place=Isfahan|year=|pages=541–542|date= February 1971|language=Persian}}</ref>

== Biography ==
Aboutorab Esfahani was born in a great rich family in [[Isfahan]].<ref>{{citation|surname1=Abd ol-Mohammad Irani|title=Peydâyeš e Xatt o Xattatan (Origin of scripts and calligraphy) |pages=123|date=  1927|language=Persian}}</ref> His birth date has not been mentioned in the historical documents, but since his death age has been mentioned 83 in one of [[Mohammad Ali Ghouchani|Mirza Sanglakh]]'s works, he must have been born in 1581.<ref>{{citation|surname1=Mirza Sanglakh|title=Tazkarat ol-Xattâtin (Calligrapher's Biography) |date=  1878|language=Persian}}</ref>

His first calligraphy teacher was Molla ALi Fayezi (death: 1626). Then Esfahani continued his education with Mir Emad. Esfahani became one of the most successful students of Mir Emad. When Mir Emad was killed in 1615, he was the only person, who dared to bury Mir Emad' body.<ref>{{citation|surname1=Mohammad Taher Nasrabadi|title=Tazkare (Biography) |pages=208|date=  1938|language=Persian}}</ref>

After Mir Emad's death, he became the most famous Persian calligrapher and he could teach many calligraphers. His most famous students were [[Mohammad Mohsen Emami]], His own sons [[Nour ed-Din Mohammad Esfahani]] and [[Mohammad Saleh Esfahani]].<ref>{{citation|surname1=Mehdi Bayani Yassavoli|title=Ahvâl o Âsâr e Xošnevisân (The Calligrapher's Biographies and Works) |publisher=Elmi|pages=767|date=  1966|language=Persian}}</ref>

He died in 1662 at the age of 83 in Isfahan and was buried in the [[Lonban mosque]].

pages.title: Abolhassan Etessami
pages.text:
[[Image:Abolhassan Etessami.jpg|thumb|right|''Abolhassan Etessami'']]

'''Abolhassan Etessami''', Iranian architect, calligrapher, painter, and novelist, was born in 1903 and died in 1978. His father Ebrahim Etessami was the head of finance of the Iranian province of [[Azerbaijan (Iran)|Azerbaijan]]; and his brother [[Yussef Etessami]] was the founder of the ''Bahar'' journal, and the father of the poet [[Parvin Etessami]].

Abolhassan Etessami was educated in [[Tehran]] at the Aghdasieh School, the American School, and the [[Kamal-ol-molk]] School of Fine Arts. Then he spent some years in [[Isfahan]] to learn architecture and decoration techniques, and later went to work at [[Tehran University]].

Abolhassan Etessami produced a series of architecture projects, detailed maquettes of which were made by himself. On the Iranian Ministry of Fine Arts' request, the maquettes were sent to [[Expo 58|Brussels' 1958 Universal Exhibition]], where Abolhassan Etessami was awarded the gold medal in the individual presentation category. The maquettes were later bought by the [[National Museum of Iran]], and included in the permanent collection of the Islamic arts division.

In addition to architecture projects, Abolhassan Etessami left a series of oil on canvas paintings including ''Some ruins in Dowlat-Abad'', ''A village home in [[Niavaran]]'', and ''Pasteur's intercession for Napoleon'', and some novels including ''The left alone man'' and ''The malicious Mohil-o-doleh''.

'''Fateh Ezatpoor''' (or Ezzatpour [https://fa.wikipedia.org/wiki/فاتح_عزت%E2%80%8Cپور], [[Persian language|Persian]]: فاتح عزت پور), son of Ahmad, born in 1958, is a [[calligrapher]], professor, and researcher.

==Education==
He is from the Jorabad quarter located in the city of [[Sanandaj]] and holds a Bachelor's degree from [[Allameh Tabatabai University]]. Mr. Ezatpoor is the official instructor of Iranian Calligraphists Association in [[Tehran]] and Sanandaj. Since 1982, he has been teaching [[calligraphy]]; in addition, he has taught this art at other Artistic and Cultural Centers; from the early years of primary education in 1969, he became acquainted with the art of calligraphy. In his household, he practiced penmanship in company with his uncle, Mehdi Kamali Kurdistani, and in 1978, he went to Tehran to continue his academic studies.

Simultaneous with his education in [[Tehran]], he did not lose his sight on practicing penmanship. In that very year, he became acquainted with the organization of Iranian Calligraphists Association; after enrolment in the presence of Prof. Abbas Akhavein (عباس اخوین), he started to acquire this art, and in 1982 he managed to receive his certificate of calligraphy with distinction from the Iranian Calligraphists Association.

After receiving his certificate of calligraphy from Iranian Calligraphists Association in Tehran, he was singled out as the official instructor and officially started to teach calligraphy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.azizihonar.com/index.php?newsid=5607|title=دیدار جمعی از هنرمندان و مسئولان استان کردستان با استاد دکتر فاتح عزت پور|work=آثار هنرمندان ایران - عزیزی هنر|access-date=2018-05-08|language=fa}}</ref> Many art learners were taught by him in various courses of the association and so far, a great number of his students have managed to receive a certificate of calligraphy with distinction from the Iranian Calligraphists Association.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.khabaronline.ir/detail/504577/provinces/kordestan|title=تجلیل از دکتر فاتح عزت پور|website=www.khabaronline.ir|language=fa|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref>

== Instructors ==
In the early days of 1969, Mr. Ezatpoor started to learn basic Nastaliq calligraphy from his uncle Mehdi Kamali Kurdistani which was his first mentor and teacher to learn Persian Calligraphy. Mr. Kamali was living in Sanandaj and was an acclaimed calligraphist at that time.

Later on, when living in Tehran, he gets the chance of being taught by Mr. Abbas Akhavein ([[عباس اخوین]]) from 1979 who is one of the best Calligraphy professors in the nation. While Mr. Ezatpoor had an outstanding performance in Nastaliq script he got interested into Shekaste script ("broken" cursive calligraphy) and from 1980 he started to learn Shekaste from Yadollah Kaboli Khansari ([[یدالله کابلی]]) in Iranian Calligraphists Association.

In addition to that, Mr. Ezatpoor's exceptional illustration skills come from Biok Ahmari from 1983. Biok Ahmari (also [[بیوک احمری]]) was one of the best illuminators at the time and his illuminations have been recognized internationally. Mr. Ezatpoor spent few years learning This (Illumination that goes around the calligraphy artworks) from Mr. Ahmari which gave him an outstanding performance to illustrate his own artworks.

Later in his artistic career, Mr. Ezatpoor continued to transfer this invaluable experience to hundreds of his students that many of them are currently professors in the field of Nastaliq and Shekaste scripts as well as Taz-hib. It worth mentioning that currently, the former students are illustrating Mr. Ezatpoor's artworks periodically.

== Artistic and Scientific Degrees Received ==
On 2009, Mr. Ezatpoor was one of the first artists in Iran that received the Certificate of Grade I (equal to Doctoral Honorary Degree) recognized by the Ministry of Sciences, Researchers and Technology<ref>Based On Official Ershad Ministry Certificate No. 3497-1/4 On 23 February 2010, Iran</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kimiyayehonar.com/705/%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%B4%D9%86%D9%88%DB%8C%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%83%D9%8F%D8%B1%D8%AF-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%AE%D8%B7-%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B9%D9%84%DB%8C%D9%82-%D9%85%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%86%D8%AF/upgrade.php|title=کیمیای هنر - خوشنویسان كُرد در خط نستعلیق ممتازند|last=هنر|first=کیمیای|website=kimiyayehonar.com|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> for his outstanding artistic work and experience. He also holds Certificate of Mastership from Iranian Calligraphists Association<ref>See Link (In Persian): http://www.ketabnews.com/detail-15412-fa-0.html</ref> as well as his BS in Economic Sciences from [[Allameh Tabataba'i University]].

== Individual and Group Exhibitions ==
Mr. Ezatpoor has served in multiple events as an international/national judge as well as several other exhibitions throughout his career. He was the international judge/mentor for the Calligraphy Contest conducted in [[Georgian National Center of Manuscripts]] on 2012,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://golestane.net/showthread.php?t=11412|title=خوشنویسی استاد فاتح عزت پور|website=golestane.net|language=fa|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gorjestan.blogfa.com/post-432.aspx|title=گرجستان - نمايشگاه آثار خوشنويسي استاد فاتح عزت پور در كشور گرجستان|website=gorjestan.blogfa.com|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> been a part of all annual World of Islam international exhibitions on professor's exhibitions, and being a judge for all Bi-Annual Persian Calligraphy conferences. Mr. Ezatpoor's mentorship events and exhibitions have been throughout the region including [[Georgia (country)]], [[Iraqi Kurdistan]], and throughout the country such as Tehran ([[Reza Abbasi Museum]], Art Gallery, Saba Gallery), Isfahan, Qeshm, and Sanandaj<ref>Iran Newspaper (In Persian) : http://iraninstitute.com/1382/820231/html/mland.htm</ref> that adds up to over 250+ exhibitions, workshops, and events.

== List of the works published and the calligraphic activities ==
Mr. Ezatpoor has published more than 14 books and some have been republished for more than 40 times.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.adinehbook.com/gp/search?search-alias=books&author=%D9%81%D8%A7%D8%AA%D8%AD+%D8%B9%D8%B2%D8%AA+%D9%BE%D9%88%D8%B1&select-author=author-exact|title=List of available books for sale at Adineh Book|last=|first=|date=|website=www.adinehbook.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-07}}</ref> Here is a list of published works:

==Writer==
During his artistic activities, Mr. Fateh Ezatpoor he has prepared and published so many articles and educational pamphlets to be used by the interested people and each of them has had a valuable role in the promotion of this art.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://tnews.ir/news/f2ff56760716.html|title=تجلیل از "فاتح عزت پور" خوشنویس برجسته کردستانی  عکاس: بختیار صمدی|last=tnews.ir|work=جستجوگر اخبار تی نیوز tnews.ir|access-date=2018-05-08|language=fa}}</ref>

In addition to artistic activities, he has been the member of Research Experts in the field of housing in Iran as well; so far he has presented and published more than forty articles in scientific journals and seminars held by the Ministry of Housing and Urban Development; in this connection, and in order  not to  prolong this piece of writing, only a part of the records of this dear instructor are pointed out.

== Artistic Professions ==

* Professor in Artistic and Scientific fields including teaching at Islamic Azad University, University of Applied Sciences and Technology, and the Center for Public Administration from 1989
* Nationwide Referee in the field of Calligraphy, and member of the Council for diagnosis and revising examination papers at Iranian Calligraphists Association from 1983.
* Teaching at [[Reza Abbasi Museum]] and Khayam Library located in Park Khayam, Tehran
* Teaching at Artistic Centers for private institutes in Tehran and Sanandaj.
* Referee of provincial competitions including students competitions, and Calligraphy Exhibitions of the provincial universities and Technical and vocational high schools. etc.
* Instructing fine penmanship at Calligraphy Classes and Teaching the civil servants employees.
* Founder and Instructor at His Artistic Work Office (Ezatpoor Art Association)

pages.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2015}}

'''Goharshad Ghazvini''', also known as '''Goharshad Hassani Ghazvini''', was a prominent [[Persian people|Persian]] [[calligrapher]] of [[Nastaʿlīq script]] in 17th century. She was [[Mir Emad]]'s daughter. She learned [[calligraphy]] when she was a teenager and learned Nastaʿlīq script from her father.<ref>{{citation
|surname1=Mehdi Bayani Yassavoli
|title=Ahvâl o Âsâr e Xošnevisân (The Biographies and Works of Calligraphers) 
|publisher=Elmi

|pages=594
|date=  1966
}}</ref>

After her father's death, she went in 1623 to her birthplace, Qazvin, and worked as a calligraphy teacher and stayed there until her death in 1628.<ref>http://iichs.org/index.asp?id=700&doc_cat=9</ref>
