pages.title: Arabic diacritics
pages.text:
{{Arabic alphabet}} The [[Arabic script]] has numerous [[diacritic]]s, including '''i'jam''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|إِعْجَام}}}} - ''{{transl|ar|ALA|i‘jām}}'', consonant pointing and '''tashkil''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|تَشْكِيل}}}} - ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tashkīl}}'', supplementary diacritics. The latter include the '''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|حَرَكَات}}}} vowel marks - singular: ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakah}}'' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|حَرَكَة}}}}. The Arabic script is an impure [[abjad]], where short consonants and long vowels are represented by letters but short vowels and consonant length are not generally indicated in writing. ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Tashkīl}}'' is optional to represent missing vowels and consonant length. Modern Arabic is always written with the ''i‘jām'' - consonant pointing, but only religious texts, children's books and works for learners are written with the full ''tashkīl'' - vowel guides and consonant length. == {{anchor|Tashkil}}Tashkil (marks used as phonetic guides) == The literal meaning of ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tashkīl}}'' is 'forming'. As the normal Arabic text does not provide enough information about the correct pronunciation, the main purpose of ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tashkīl}}'' (and ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'') is to provide a phonetic guide or a phonetic aid; i.e. show the correct pronunciation. It serves the same purpose as [[furigana]] (also called "ruby") in [[Japanese language|Japanese]] or [[pinyin]] or [[zhuyin]] in [[Mandarin Chinese]] for children who are learning to read or foreign learners. The bulk of Arabic script is written without ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' (or short vowels). However, they are commonly used in texts that demand strict adherence to exact wording. This is true, primarily, of the [[Qur'an]] {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|الْقُرْآن}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|al-Qur’ān}}'') and [[w:Arabic poetry|poetry]]. It is also quite common to add ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' to [[hadith]]s {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|الْحَدِيث}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|al-ḥadīth}}''; plural: ''{{transl|ar|ALA|aḥādīth}}'') and the [[w:Bible translations into Arabic|Bible]]. Another use is in children's literature. Moreover, ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' are used in ordinary texts in individual words when an ambiguity of pronunciation cannot easily be resolved from context alone. Arabic dictionaries with vowel marks provide information about the correct pronunciation to both native and foreign Arabic speakers. In art and [[calligraphy]], ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' might be used simply because their writing is considered [[aesthetics|aesthetically]] pleasing. An example of a fully ''vocalised'' (''vowelised'' or ''vowelled'') Arabic from the ''[[Basmala]]'': {{Quote|{{lang|ar| بِسْمِ ٱللهِ ٱلرَّحْمٰنِ ٱلرَّحِيمِ }}
''{{transl|ar|ALA|Bismi Llāhi r-Raḥmāni r-Raḥīmi}}''
In the Name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful...}} Some Arabic textbooks for foreigners now use ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' as a phonetic guide to make learning reading Arabic easier. The other method used in textbooks is phonetic [[Romanization of Arabic|romanisation]] of unvocalised texts. Fully vocalised Arabic texts (i.e. Arabic texts with ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}''/diacritics) are sought after by learners of Arabic. Some online bilingual dictionaries also provide ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' as a phonetic guide similarly to English dictionaries providing transcription. ===Harakat (short vowel marks) {{anchor|ḥarakāt|harakat}} === The ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'', which literally means 'motions', are the short vowel marks. There is some ambiguity as to which ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tashkīl}}'' are also ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}''; the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tanwīn}}'', for example, are markers for both vowels and consonants. ====Fatḥah==== {{Redirect|Fatha|the jazz pianist|Earl Hines}}
{{lang|ar|ـَ}}
The '''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatḥah}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|فَتْحَة}}}} is a small diagonal line placed ''above'' a letter, and represents a short {{IPA|/a/}} (like the initial sound in English word "up"). The word ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatḥah}}'' itself ({{lang|ar|فَتْحَة}}) means ''opening'' and refers to the opening of the mouth when producing an {{IPA|/a/}}. For example, with ''[[Dalet|{{transl|ar|ALA|dāl}}]]'' (henceforth, the base consonant in the following examples): {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|دَ}}}} {{IPA|/da/}}. When a '''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatḥah}}''' is placed before a plain letter {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ا}}}} (''[[Aleph|{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}]]'') (i.e. one having no hamza or vowel of its own), it represents a long {{IPA|/aː/}} (as in the English word "father"). For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|دَا}}}} {{IPA|/daː/}}. The ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatḥah}}'' is not usually written in such cases. When a fathah placed before the letter ⟨{{lang|ar|ﻱ}}⟩ (yā’), it creates an {{IPA|/aj/}} (as in "l'''ie'''"); and when placed before the letter ⟨{{lang|ar|و}}⟩ (wāw), it creates an {{IPA|/aw/}} (as in "c'''ow'''") {{clear}} ====Kasrah====
{{lang|ar|ـِ}}
A similar diagonal line ''below'' a letter is called a '''{{transl|ar|ALA|kasrah}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|كَسْرَة}}}} and designates a short {{IPA|/i/}} (as in "Tim") and its allophones [i, ɪ, e, e̞, ɛ]. For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|دِ}}}} {{IPA|/di/}}.{{cite web|url=http://web.uvic.ca/hrd/hist455/vowels/vowels_pres.htm|title=Introduction to Written Arabic|website=University of Victoria, Canada}} When a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|kasrah}}'' is placed before a plain letter {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ﻱ}}}} (''[[ي|{{transl|ar|ALA|yā’}}]]''), it represents a long {{IPA|/iː/}} (as in the English word "steed"). For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|دِي}}}} {{IPA|/diː/}}. The ''{{transl|ar|ALA|kasrah}}'' is usually not written in such cases, but if ''[[ي|{{transl|ar|ALA|yā’}}]]'' is pronounced as a diphthong {{IPA|/aj/}}, ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatḥah}}'' should be written on the preceding consonant to avoid mispronunciation. The word ''{{transl|ar|ALA|kasrah}}'' means 'breaking'. {{clear}} ====Ḍammah====
{{lang|ar|ـُ}}
The '''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḍammah}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ضَمَّة}}}} is a small curl-like diacritic placed above a letter to represent a short /u/ (as in "put") and its allophones [u, ʊ, o, o̞, ɔ]. For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|دُ}}}} {{IPA|/du/}}. When a '''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḍammah}}''' is placed before a plain letter {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|و}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|[[wāw]]}}''), it represents a long {{IPA|/uː/}} (like the 'oo' sound in the English word "swoop"). For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|دُو}}}} {{IPA|/duː/}}. The ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḍammah}}'' is usually not written in such cases, but if ''{{transl|ar|ALA|wāw}}'' is pronounced as a diphthong {{IPA|/aw/}}, ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatḥah}}'' should be written on the preceding consonant to avoid mispronunciation. {{clear}} ====Alif Khanjariyah====
{{lang|ar|ــٰ}}
The [[Dagger alif|'''superscript (or dagger) ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}''''']] {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|أَلِف خَنْجَرِيَّة}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif khanjarīyah}}''), is written as short vertical stroke on top of a consonant. It indicates a long {{IPA|/aː/}} sound for which ''[[Aleph#Arabic|{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}]]'' is normally not written. For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|هَٰذَا}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|hādhā}}'') or {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|رَحْمَٰن}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|raḥmān}}''). The dagger ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' occurs in only a few words, but they include some common ones; it is seldom written, however, even in fully vocalised texts. Most keyboards do not have dagger ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}.'' The word [[Allah]] {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|الله}}}} ({{transl|ar|ALA|''Allāh''}}) is usually produced automatically by entering ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif lām lām hāʾ}}.'' The word consists of ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' + ligature of doubled ''{{transl|ar|ALA|lām}}'' with a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|shaddah}}'' and a dagger ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' above ''{{transl|ar|ALA|lām}}''. {{clear}} ===Maddah=== {{distinguish|Maddah (religious singer)|Maddahi}}
{{lang|ar|ـٓ}}
The '''{{transl|ar|ALA|maddah}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|مَدَّة}}}} is a [[tilde]]-shaped diacritic, which can appear mostly on top of an ''[[Aleph|{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}]]'' and indicates a [[glottal stop]] {{IPA|/ʔ/}} followed by a long {{IPA|/aː/}}. In theory, the same sequence {{IPA|/ʔaː/}} could also be represented by two ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}''s, as in *{{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|أَا}}}}, where a hamza above the first ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' represents the {{IPA|/ʔ/}} while the second ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' represents the {{IPA|/aː/}}. However, consecutive ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}''s are never used in the Arabic orthography. Instead, this sequence must always be written as a single ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' with a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|maddah}}'' above it, the combination known as an ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maddah}}''. For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|قُرْآن}}}} {{IPA|/qurˈʔaːn/}}. ===Alif waslah=== {{main|Wasla (diacritic)}}
{{lang|ar|ٱ}}
The '''{{transl|ar|ALA|waṣlah}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|وَصْلَة}}}}, '''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif waṣlah}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|أَلِف وَصْلَة}}}} or '''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzat waṣl}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|هَمْزَة وَصْل}}}} looks like a small letter ''[[Tsade#Arabic Ṣād|{{transl|ar|ALA|ṣād}}]]'' on top of an ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ٱ}}}} (also indicated by an ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ا}}}} without a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzah}}''). It means that the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' is not pronounced when its word begins a sentence. For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|بِٱسْمِ}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|bismi}}''), but {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ٱمْشُوا۟}}}} (''imshū'' not ''mshū''). This is because no Arab word can start with a vowel-less consonant (unlike the English ''school'', or ''skateboard''). But when it happens, an ''alif'' is added to obtain a vowel or a vowelled consonant at the beginning of one's speech. In English that would result in ''iskool'', or ''iskateboard''. It occurs only in the beginning of words, but it can occur after prepositions and the definite article. It is commonly found in imperative verbs, the perfective aspect of verb stems VII to X and their [[Arabic_verbs#Masdar|verbal nouns]] (''{{transl|ar|ALA|maṣdar}}''). The ''alif'' of the definite article is considered a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|waṣlah}}''. {{clear}} It occurs in phrases and sentences (connected speech, not isolated/dictionary forms): * To replace the elided hamza whose alif-seat has assimilated to the previous vowel. For example: {{lang|ar|فِي ٱلْيَمَن}} or {{lang|ar|في اليمن}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|fi l-Yaman}}'') ‘in Yemen’. * In hamza-initial imperative forms following a vowel, especially following the conjunction {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|و}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|wa-}}'') ‘and’. For example: َ{{lang|ar|قُمْ وَٱشْرَبِ ٱلْمَاءَ}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|qum wa-shrab-i l-mā’}}'') ‘rise and then drink the water’. ===Sukun===
{{lang|ar|ـْـ}}
The '''{{transl|ar|ALA|sukūn}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|سُكُون}}}} is a circle-shaped diacritic placed above a letter. It indicates that the consonant to which it is attached is not followed by a vowel. It is a necessary symbol for writing consonant-vowel-consonant syllables, which are very common in Arabic. For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|دَدْ}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|dad}}''). The '''{{transl|ar|ALA|sukūn}}''' may also be used to help represent a diphthong. A ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatḥah}}'' followed by the letter {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ﻱ}}}} (''[[yodh|{{transl|ar|ALA|yā’}}]]'') with a {{transl|ar|ALA|sukūn}} over it ({{rtl-lang|ar|ـَيْ}}) indicates the diphthong ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ay}}'' ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] {{IPA|/aj/}}). A ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatḥah}}'', followed by the letter {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ﻭ}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|[[wāw]]}}'') with a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|sukūn}}'', ({{rtl-lang|ar|ـَوْ}}) indicates {{IPA|/aw/}}.
{{lang|ar|ـۡـ}}
The '''{{transl|ar|ALA|sukūn}}''' may have also an alternative form of the small high dotless head of [[Ḫāʾ|''{{transl|ar|ALA|khāʾ}}'']] ({{unichar|06E1}}), particularly in some Qurans. Other shapes may exist as well (for example, like a small comma above ⟨ʼ⟩ or like a [[circumflex]] ⟨ˆ⟩ in [[Nastaʿlīq script|''{{transl|ar|ALA|nastaʿlīq}}'']]).{{cite web|url=https://r12a.github.io/scripts/arabic/block#char0652|title=Arabic character notes|website=r12a}} {{clear}} === {{anchor|Tanwin}}Tanwin (final postnasalized or long vowels) === {{main|Nunation}}
{{lang|ar|ـٌ}}  {{lang|ar|ـٍ}}  {{lang|ar|ـً}}
The three vowel diacritics may be doubled at the end of a word to indicate that the vowel is followed by the consonant ''n''. They may or may not be considered {{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}} and are known as '''{{transl|ar|ALA|tanwīn}}''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|تَنْوِين}}}}, or nunation. The signs indicate, from right to left, {{transl|ar|ALA|''-un, -in, -an}}''. These endings are used as non-pausal grammatical indefinite case endings in [[Modern Standard Arabic|Literary Arabic]] or [[classical Arabic]] ([[ʾIʿrab#Fully declined nouns (triptote مُنْصَرِف munṣarif)|triptotes]] only). In a vocalised text, they may be written even if they are not pronounced (see [[pausa]]). See ''[[ʾIʿrab|{{transl|ar|ALA|i‘rāb]]}}'' for more details. In many spoken Arabic dialects, the endings are absent. Many Arabic textbooks introduce standard Arabic without these endings. The grammatical endings may not be written in some vocalized Arabic texts, as knowledge of ''[[ʾIʿrab|{{transl|ar|ALA|i‘rāb}}]]'' varies from country to country, and there is a trend towards simplifying Arabic grammar. The sign {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ـً}}}} is most commonly written in combination with {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ـًا}}}} (''[[aleph|{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}]]''), {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ةً}}}} (''[[Ta' marbuta|{{transl|ar|ALA|tā’ marbūṭah}}]]''), {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|أً}}}} (alif hamzah) or stand-alone {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ءً}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|[[hamza]]h}}''). ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Alif}}'' should always be written (except for words ending in ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tā’ marbūṭah, hamzah}}'' or diptotes) even if ''{{transl|ar|ALA|an}}'' is not. Grammatical cases and ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tanwīn}}'' endings in indefinite triptote forms: * ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-un}}'': [[nominative case]]; * ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-an}}'': [[accusative case]], also serves as an adverbial marker; * ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-in}}'': [[genitive case]]. {{clear}} ===Shaddah (consonant gemination mark)=== {{main|Shadda}}
{{lang|ar|ـّـ}}
The '''shadda''' or '''shaddah''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|شَدَّة}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|shaddah}}''), or '''tashdid''' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|تَشْدِيد}}}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|tashdīd}}''), is a diacritic shaped like a small written Latin "[[w]]". It is used to indicate [[gemination]] (consonant doubling or extra length), which is phonemic in Arabic. It is written above the consonant which is to be doubled. It is the only ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakah}}'' that is sometimes used in ordinary spelling to avoid [[ambiguity]]. For example: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|دّ}}}} {{IPA|/dd/}}; ''{{transl|ar|ALA|madrasah}}'' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|مَدْرَسَة}}}} ('school') vs. ''{{transl|ar|ALA|mudarrisah}}'' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|مُدَرِّسَة}}}} ('teacher', female). {{clear}} == {{anchor|I'jam}}I‘jām (phonetic distinctions of consonants) == [[Image:Kufic Quran, sura 7, verses 86-87.jpg|thumb|right|7th-century [[kufic]] script without either ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' or ''{{transl|ar|ALA|i‘jām}}''.]] The ''i‘jām'' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|إِعْجَام}}}} (sometimes also called ''nuqaṭ''){{cite book |title=What the Koran Really Says : Language, Text & Commentary |publisher=Prometheus |year=2002 |isbn=157392945X |editor-last=Ibn Warraq |author1=Ibn Warraq |authorlink1=Ibn Warraq |location=New York |url=https://www.ebooklibs.co/book/view/1m41/what-the-koran-really-says.html |translator-last=Ibn Warraq |page=64 |accessdate=9 April 2019 |ref=WtKRS-I-IW2002}} are the diacritic points that distinguish various consonants that have the same form (''{{transl|ar|ALA|[[rasm]]}}''), such as {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ـبـ}}}} {{IPA|/b/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ـتـ}}}} {{IPA|/t/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ـثـ}}}} {{IPA|/θ/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ـنـ}}}} {{IPA|/n/}}, and {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ـيـ}}}} {{IPA|/j/}}. Typically ''i‘jām'' are not considered diacritics but part of the letter. Early manuscripts of the ''[[Qur'an|{{transl|ar|ALA|Qur’ān}}]]'' did not use diacritics either for vowels or to distinguish the different values of the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|rasm}}.'' Vowel pointing was introduced first, as a red dot placed above, below, or beside the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|rasm}}'', and later consonant pointing was introduced, as thin, short black single or multiple dashes placed above or below the ''rasm'' ([[#History|image]]). These ''i‘jām'' became black dots about the same time as the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' became small black letters or strokes. Typically, Egyptians do not use dots under final ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yā’}}'' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ي}}}}, which looks exactly like ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maqṣūrah}}'' {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ى}}}} in handwriting and in print. This practice is also used in copies of the ''[[Mus'haf|{{transl|ar|ALA|muṣḥaf}}]]'' ([[Qurʾān]]) scribed by [[Uthman Taha|{{transl|ar|ALA|‘Uthman Ṭāhā}}]]. The same unification of ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yā}}'' and ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maqṣūrā}}'' has happened in [[Persian language|Persian]], resulting in what [[the Unicode Standard]] calls "{{smallcaps|arabic letter farsi yeh}}", that looks exactly the same as ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yā}}'' in initial and medial forms, but exactly the same as ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maqṣūrah}}'' in final and isolated forms {{angle bracket|{{lang|fa|یـ  ـیـ  ـی}}}}.
{{lang|ar|سـۡ سـۜ سۣـ سـٚ سٜـ ڛـ}}
At the time when the ''i‘jām'' was optional, letters deliberately lacking the points of ''i‘jām'': {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ح}}}} {{IPA|/ħ/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|د}}}} {{IPA|/d/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ر}}}} {{IPA|/r/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|س}}}} {{IPA|/s/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ص}}}} {{IPA|/sˤ/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ط}}}} {{IPA|/tˤ/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ع}}}} {{IPA|/ʕ/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ل}}}} {{IPA|/l/}}, {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ه}}}} {{IPA|/h/}} — could be marked with a small v-shaped sign above or below the letter, or a semicircle, or a miniature of the letter itself (e.g. a small [[س]] to indicate that the letter in question is س and not [[ش]]), or one or several subscript dots, or a superscript ''[[hamza]]'', or a superscript stroke.{{cite book|last=Gacek|first=Adam|title=Arabic Manuscripts: A Vademecum for Readers|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NeaHnLb6RdUC&pg=PA286|year=2009|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-17036-7|page=286|chapter=Unpointed letters}} These signs, collectively known as ''‘alāmātu-l-ihmāl'', are still occasionally used in modern [[Arabic calligraphy]], either for their original purpose (i.e. marking letters without ''i‘jām''), or often as purely decorative space-fillers. The small ک above the [[ك|''kāf'']] in its final and isolated forms {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ك  ـك}}}} was originally ''‘alāmatu-l-ihmāl'', but became a permanent part of the letter. Previously this sign could also appear above the medial form of ''kāf'', instead of the stroke on its [[ascender (typography)|ascender]].{{cite book|title=Les manuscrits du Moyen-Orient: essais de codicologie et de paléographie. Actes du colloque d'Istanbul (Istanbul 26–29 mai 1986)|last=Gacek|first=Adam|date=1989|publisher=|year=|isbn=|editor=Déroche|editor-first=François|editor-link=François Déroche|location=|page=57 (§8. Diacritical marks and vowelisation)|pages=|chapter=Technical Practices and Recommendations Recorded by Classical and Post-Classical Arabic Scholars Concerning the Copying and Correction of Manuscripts|chapter-url=http://www.islamicmanuscripts.info/reference/books/Deroche-1989-MMO/MMO-1989-051-060-Gacek.pdf}} == {{anchor|Hamza}}Hamza (glottal stop semi-consonant) == {{main|Hamza}}
{{lang|ar|ئ  ؤ  إ  أ ء}}
Although often a diacritic is not considered a letter of the alphabet, the '''hamza''' {{lang|ar|هَمْزَة}} (''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzah}}'', [[glottal stop]]), often stands as a separate letter in writing, is written in unpointed texts and is not considered a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|tashkīl}}.'' It may appear as a letter by itself or as a diacritic over or under an ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'', ''{{transl|ar|ALA|wāw}}'', or ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yā}}''. Which letter is to be used to support the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzah}}'' depends on the quality of the adjacent vowels; * If the glottal stop occurs at the beginning of the word, it is always indicated by hamza on an ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'': above if the following vowel is {{IPA|/a/}} or {{IPA|/u/}} and below if it is {{IPA|/i/}}. * If the glottal stop occurs in the middle of the word, ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzah}}'' above ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' is used only if it is not preceded or followed by {{IPA|/i/}} or {{IPA|/u/}}: ** If {{IPA|/i/}} is before or after the glottal stop, a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|[[yāʼ]]}}'' with a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzah}}'' is used (the two dots which are usually beneath the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yāʾ}}'' disappear in this case): {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ئ}}}}. ** Otherwise, if {{IPA|/u/}} is before or after the glottal stop, a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|[[wāw]]}}'' with a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzah}}'' is used: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|ؤ}}}}. * If the glottal stop occurs at the end of the word (ignoring any grammatical suffixes), if it follows a short vowel it is written above ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'', ''{{transl|ar|ALA|wāw}}'', or ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yā}}'' the same as for a medial case; otherwise on the line (i.e. if it follows a long vowel, diphthong or consonant). * Two ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}''s in succession are never allowed: {{IPA|/ʔaː/}} is written with ''[[#Maddah|{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maddah}}]]'' {{angbr|{{lang|ar|آ}}}} and {{IPA|/aːʔ/}} is written with a free ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hamzah}}'' on the line {{angbr|{{lang|ar|اء}}}}. Consider the following words: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|أَخ}}}} {{IPA|/ʔax/}} ("brother"), {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|إِسماعيل}}}} {{IPA|/ʔismaːʕiːl/}} ("Ismael"), {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|أُمّ}}}} {{IPA|/ʔumm/}} ("mother"). All three of above words "begin" with a vowel opening the syllable, and in each case, ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif}}'' is used to designate the initial glottal stop (the ''actual'' beginning). But if we consider ''middle'' syllables "beginning" with a vowel: {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|نَشْأَة}}}} {{IPA|/naʃʔa/}} ("origin"), {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|أْفِئدة}}}} {{IPA|/ʔafʔida/}} ("hearts" — notice the {{IPA|/ʔi/}} syllable; singular {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|فُؤَاد}}}} {{IPA|/fuʔaːd/}}), {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|رُؤُوس}}}} {{IPA|/ruʔuːs/}} ("heads", singular {{angle bracket|{{lang|ar|رَأْس}}}} {{IPA|/raʔs/}}), the situation is different, as noted above. See the comprehensive article on ''{{transl|ar|ALA|[[hamza]]h}}'' for more details. {{clear}} ==History== [[Image:Arabic script evolution.svg|thumb|250px| Evolution of early Arabic calligraphy (9th–11th century). The [[w:Basmala|Basmala]] was taken as an example, from [[w:Kufic|kufic]] ''[[w:Qur’an|{{transl|ar|ALA|Qur’ān}}]]'' manuscripts.
(1) Early 9th century, script with no dots or diacritic marks (see [[:Image:Basmala kufi.svg|image of early Basmala Kufic]]);
(2) and (3) 9th–10th century under Abbasid dynasty, Abu al-Aswad's system established red dots with each arrangement or position indicating a different short vowel; later, a second black-dot system was used to differentiate between letters like ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fā’}}'' and ''{{transl|ar|ALA|qāf}}'' (see [[:Image:Kufi.jpg|image of middle Kufic]]);
(4) 11th century, in al-Farāhídi's system (system we know today) dots were changed into shapes resembling the letters to transcribe the corresponding long vowels (see [[:Image:Qur'an folio 11th century kufic.jpg|image of modern Kufic in Qur'an]]). ]] According to tradition, the first to commission a system of ''harakat'' was [[Ali]] who appointed [[Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali]] for the task. Abu al-Aswad devised a system of dots to signal the three short vowels (along with their respective allophones) of Arabic. This system of dots predates the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|i‘jām}}'', dots used to distinguish between different consonants. Image:Basmala kufi.svg|Early Basmala Kufic Image:Kufi.jpg|Middle Kufic Image:Qur'an folio 11th century kufic.jpg|Modern Kufic in Qur'an ===Abu al-Aswad's system=== Abu al-Aswad's system of Harakat was different from the system we know today. The system used red dots with each arrangement or position indicating a different short vowel. A dot above a letter indicated the vowel ''{{transl|ar|ALA|a}}'', a dot below indicated the vowel ''{{transl|ar|ALA|i}}'', a dot on the side of a letter stood for the vowel ''{{transl|ar|ALA|u}}'', and two dots stood for the ''[[tanwin|{{transl|ar|ALA|tanwīn}}]]''. However, the early manuscripts of the Qur'an did not use the vowel signs for every letter requiring them, but only for letters where they were necessary for a correct reading. ===Al Farahidi's system=== This is the precursor to the system we know today. ''[[Al Farāhídi|{{transl|ar|ALA|al-Farāhīdī}}]]'' found that the task of writing using two different colours was tedious and impractical. Another complication was that the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|i‘jām}}'' had been introduced by then, which, while they were short strokes rather than the round dots seen today, meant that without a color distinction the two could become confused. Accordingly, he replaced the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' with small superscript letters: small alif, yā’, and wāw for the short vowels corresponding to the long vowels written with those letters, a small ''s(h)īn'' for ''shaddah'' (geminate), a small ''khā’'' for ''khafīf'' (short consonant; no longer used). His system is essentially the one we know today.{{cite book|last=Versteegh|first=C. H. M.|title=The Arabic Language|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2tghviSsrF8C|year=1997|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-11152-2|pages=56ff}} ==See also== * [[Arabic alphabet]]: ** ''[[ʾIʿrab|{{transl|ar|ALA|I‘rāb}}]]'' ({{rtl-lang|ar|إِﻋْﺮَﺍﺏ}}), the case system of Arabic ** ''[[Rasm|{{transl|ar|ALA|Rasm}}]]'' ({{rtl-lang|ar|رَسْم}}), the basic system of Arabic consonants ** ''[[Tajwid|{{transl|ar|ALA|Tajwīd}}]]'' ({{rtl-lang|ar|تَجْوِيد}}), the phonetic rules of recitation of Qur'an in Arabic * ''[[Niqqud]],'' the [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] equivalent of ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ḥarakāt}}'' * ''[[Dagesh]],'' the Hebrew diacritic similar to Arabic ''{{transl|ar|ALA|i‘jām}}'' and shaddah == References == {{reflist}} * [https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-02113751 '' Alexis Neme and Sébastien Paumier (2019), Restoring Arabic vowels through omission-tolerant dictionary lookup, Lang Resources & Evaluation, Vol 53, 1-65 pages''] ==External links== * [http://www.harakat.ae/ Online Arabic Diacritic Tool by Multillect] {{Arabic language}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arabic Diacritics}} [[Category:Arabic diacritics| ]] [[Category:Arabic words and phrases]] [[Category:Quranic orthography]] [[Category:Phonetic guides]]

pages.title: Dagger alif
pages.text:
[[File:khanjariah.png|thumb|150px|Alif maqṣūra with alif khanjariya above it]]
{{lang|ar|ــٰ}}
The '''dagger alif''' or '''superscript alif''' ({{lang-ar|ألف خنجرية}} {{transl|ar|ALA|''alif khanjariyya''}}) is written as a short vertical stroke on top of an [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic letter]]. It indicates a long {{IPA|/aː/}} sound where [[aleph|alif]] is normally not written, e.g. {{lang|ar|هٰذَا}} {{transl|ar|ALA|''hādhā''}} or {{lang|ar|رَحْمٰن}} {{transl|ar|ALA|''raḥmān''}}. The dagger alif occurs in only a few modern words, but these include some common ones; it is seldom written, however, even in fully vocalised texts, excepting the [[Qur'an]]. As [[William Wright (orientalist)|Wright]] notes "[alif] was at first more rarely marked than the other long vowels, and hence it happens that, at a later period, after the invention of the vowel-points, it was indicated in some very common words merely by a fètḥa [i.e. the dagger alif.]" Most keyboards do not have dagger alif. The word {{lang|ar|[[ﷲ]]}} ({{transl|ar|ALA|''Allāh''}}) is usually produced automatically by entering "{{transl|ar|ALA|''alif lām lām hāʾ''}}". The word consists of alif + [[Typographic ligature|ligature]] of doubled {{transl|ar|ALA|lām}} with a [[shadda]] and a dagger alif above {{transl|ar|ALA|lām}}. == With fatḥah == There are two possible ways of representing the dagger alif in modern editions of Quran. In the editions printed in the Middle East the dagger alif is written with ''fatḥah'': {{lang|ar|الرَّحْمَٰنِ}} {{transl|ar|ALA|''(a)r-raḥmān''}}. In the editions printed in South Asia (Pakistan, India and Bangladesh) the dagger alif is written without ''fatḥah'': {{lang|ar|الرَّحْمٰنِ}} {{transl|ar|ALA|''(a)r-raḥmāni''}}. == See also == * [[Arabic diacritics]] == References == {{cite book|last1=Caspari|first1=Carl Paul|authorlink1=Carl Paul Caspari|editor1-last=Wright|editor1-first=William|editor2-last=Smith|editor2-first=William Robertson|editor3-last=de Goeje|editor3-first=Michael Jan|editor1-link=William Wright (orientalist)|editor2-link=William Robertson Smith|editor3-link=Michael Jan de Goeje|title=A Grammar of the Arabic Language|volume=1|date=1896|pages=9–10|edition=3rd|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gpu8uyjN1tkC&pg=PA9}} {{cite book|last1=Ryding|first1=Karin C.|title=A Reference Grammar of Modern Standard Arabic|date=2005|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=28|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hF_P3UpKZMkC&pg=PA28&}} {{cite book|last1=Alhawary|first1=Mohammad T.|title=Modern standard Arabic grammar: a learner's guide|date=2011|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-1-4051-5501-4|pages=17–18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0pogWZpMbNYC&pg=PA17}} {{Arabic language}} [[Category:Arabic diacritics]] [[Category:Arabic words and phrases]] [[Category:Quranic orthography]] [[Category:Phonetic guides]] {{arabic-script-stub}}

pages.title: Shadda
pages.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2012}} [[Image:00-Taschdid.svg|thumb]] '''Shaddah''' ({{lang-ar|شَدّة}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|shaddah}}'' "[sign of] emphasis", also called by the verbal noun from the same root, '''tashdid''' {{Lang|ar|تشديد}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|tashdīd}}'' "emphasis") is one of the [[Arabic diacritics|diacritics]] used with the [[Arabic alphabet]], marking a long consonant ([[gemination|geminate]]). It is functionally equivalent to writing a consonant twice in the orthographies of languages like [[Latin]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Swedish language|Swedish]], and [[Ancient Greek]], and is thus rendered in Latin script in most schemes of [[Arabic transliteration]], e.g. {{lang|ar|رُمّان}} = ''{{transl|ar|ALA|rummān}}'' '[[pomegranates]]'. ==Form== In shape, it is a small letter {{lang|ar|س}} ''[[shin (letter)#Arabic šīn/sīn|s(h)in]]'', standing for ''shaddah''. It was devised for poetry by [[al-Khalil ibn Ahmad]] in the eighth century, replacing an earlier dot.Versteegh, 1997. ''The Arabic language''. p 56. {|class="wikitable" |- !General
Unicode !Name !Transliteration |- style="text-align:center;" |style="line-height:180%;padding:10px;"|0651
{{rtl-lang|ar| ّ }} ّ |{{transl|ar|ALA|shaddah}} |(consonant doubled) |} ==Combination with other diacritics== When a shadda is used on a consonant which also takes a ''{{transl|ar|ALA|fatḥah}}'' {{IPA|/a/}}, it is written above the shaddah, while if it had a [[Harakat#Kasra|''{{transl|ar|ALA|kasrah}}'']] (a dash below the consonant indicating that it takes a short {{IPA|/i/}} as its vowel), the kasrah is written between the consonant and the ''{{transl|ar|ALA|shaddah}}'', under the shaddah, rather than in its normal place. ==Significance of marking consonant length== Consonant length in Arabic is contrastive: {{Lang|ar|دَرَسَ}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|darasa}}'' means 'he studied' while {{Lang|ar|دَرَّسَ}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|darrasa}}'' means 'he taught'; {{Lang|ar|بَكى صَبي}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|bakā ṣabiyy}}'' means 'a youth cried' while {{Lang|ar|بَكّى الصَّبي}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|bakkā ṣ-ṣabiyy}}'' means 'a youth was made to cry'. A consonant may be long because of the form of the noun or verb; e.g., the causative form of the verb requires the 2nd consonant of the root to be long, as in ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|darrasa}}'' above, or by assimilation of consonants, for example the ''{{Transl|ar|l-}}'' of the [[Al-|Arabic definite article]] ''al-'' assimilates to all dental consonants, e.g. ({{lang|ar|الصّبي}}) ''{{Transl|ar|(a)ṣ-ṣabiyy}}'' instead of ''{{Transl|ar|(a)l-ṣabiyy}}'', or through [[metathesis (linguistics)|metathesis]], the switching of sounds, for example {{Lang|ar|أَقَلّ}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|aqall}}'' 'less, fewer' (instead of *{{Lang|ar|أَقْلَل}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|aqlal}}''), as compared to {{Lang|ar|أَكْبَر}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|akbar}}'' 'greater'. A syllable closed by a long consonant is made a long syllable. This affects both stress and prosody. Stress falls on the first long syllable from the end of the word, hence {{Lang|ar|أَقَلّ}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|aqáll}}'' (or, with [[i`rab|{{transl|ar|ALA|iʻrāb}}]]: ''{{Transl|ar|aqállu}}'') as opposed to {{Lang|ar|أَكْبَر}} ''{{Transl|ar|ákbar}}'', {{Lang|ar|مَحَبّة}} {{Transl|ar|''maḥábbah''}} 'love, [[agape]]' as opposed to {{Lang|ar|مَعْرِفة}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|maʻrifah}}'' '(experiential) knowledge'. In Arabic [[Verse (poetry)|verse]], when scanning the meter, a syllable closed by a long consonant is counted as long, just like any other syllable closed by a consonant or a syllable ending in a long vowel: {{Lang|ar|أَلا تَمْدَحَنَّ}} ''{{Transl|ar|ALA|a-lā tamdaḥanna}}'' 'Will you not indeed praise...?' is scanned as ''{{Transl|ar|a-lā tam-da-ḥan-na}}'': short, long, long, short, long, short. ==See also== * [[Arabic diacritics]] * [[Arabic alphabet]] * [[Dagesh#Dagesh_hazak|Dagesh ḥazak]], a functionally similar diacritic used to indicate gemination in [[Biblical Hebrew]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Arabic diacritics]] {{arabic-script-stub}}

pages.title: Wasla
pages.text:
{{lang|ar|ٱ}}
The '''''waṣla''''' ({{lang-ar|{{wikt-lang|ar|وَصْلَة}}|lit=an instance of connection}}) or '''{{transl|ar|hamzatu l-waṣli}}''' ({{lang|ar|هَمْزَةُ ٱلْوَصْلِ}}, '[[hamza]] of connection') is an [[Arabic script|Arabic]] [[diacritic]] resembling part of the letter [[tsade|{{transl|ar|ṣād}}]] ({{lang|ar|ص}}) that is sometimes placed over the letter [[aleph|{{transl|ar|ʾalif}}]] at the beginning of the word ({{lang|ar|[[wikt:ٱ|ٱ]]}}). The ''ʾalif'' with ''waṣla'' over it is called the {{transl|ar|ʾalifu l-waṣli}} ({{lang|ar|أَلِفُ ٱلْوَصْلِ}}, 'aleph of connection'). It indicates that the alif is not pronounced as a glottal stop (written with the letter or diacritic ''[[hamza]]'' {{lang|ar|ء}}), but that the word is connected to the previous word (like [[liaison (French)|liaison]] in [[French language|French]]). Outside of [[Vocalised Arabic|vocalised]] texts, the {{transl|ar|waṣla}} is usually not written.{{cite web | last = Alhonen | first = Miikka-Markus | title = Proposal for encoding the combining diacritic Arabic wasla | url = https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2003/03166-wasla.pdf | publisher = unicode.org | accessdate = 25 March 2014}}{{cite web | last = Price | first = James M | title = Helping Vowels and the Elidable Hamza | url = http://allthearabicyouneverlearnedthefirsttimearound.com/p1/p1-ch1/helping-vowels-and-the-elidable-hamza/ | publisher = Arabic Language Lessons: All The Arabic You Never Learned The First Time Around | accessdate = 25 March 2014}} == Examples == # {{lang|ar|وَٱسْمُ ٱبْنَتِهِ هِنْدُ}} ({{transl|ar|wa-smu bnati-hi hindu}}) — And his daughter's name is Hind. # {{lang|ar|يُرِيدُ أَنْ يُنْكِحَ إِحْدَى ٱبْنَتَيِهِ}} ({{transl|ar|yurīdu ʾan yunkiḥa iḥdā bnatayi-hi}}) — He wants to marry one of his daughters. # {{lang|ar|مَا ٱسْمُكَ}} ({{transl|ar|mā smu-ka}}) — What is your name? ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Arabic diacritics]] {{linguistics-stub}} {{arabic-script-stub}}

pages.title: B̤ē
pages.text:
{{Arabic alphabet}}
{{Arabic-script sidebar|Saraiki}}

'''B̤ē''' ({{lang-sd|ٻ}}) is an additional letter of the [[Arabic script]], derived from [[bāʼ]] ({{lang-ar|ب}}) with an additional [[dot (diacritic)|dot]]. It is not used in the [[Arabic alphabet]] itself, but is used to represent the sound {{IPAblink|ɓ}} when writing [[Hausa language|Hausa]], [[Saraiki language|Saraiki]], and [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] in the Arabic script. The same sound may also be written simply as bāʾ in Hausa, undifferentiated from {{IPAblink|b}}.

{{Arabic alphabet shapes|ٻ}}

Both Hausa and Sindhi are also written in scripts besides Arabic. The sound represented by b̤ē is written [[Ɓ|Ɓ ɓ]] in Hausa's [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[orthography]], and written {{lang|hi|[[ॿ]]}} in Saraiki and Sindhi's [[Devanagari]] orthography.
